            <meta content="How far can you go with Vanilla JS?" itemprop="name" data-reactid="82">
            <h1 data-reactid="83" itemprop="headline"><a data-reactid="84" href="/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn">How far can you go with Vanilla JS?</a></h1>
            <span data-reactid="85">
             <meta content="17" itemprop="upvoteCount" data-reactid="86">
             <meta content="8" itemprop="answerCount" data-reactid="87"></span>
           </div>
           <div data-reactid="88" class="post-meta-desc">
            <div data-reactid="89" itemprop="description">
             <p>Of course, ultimately, all frameworks become vanilla js under the hood, but given the advances of HTML, CSS, and ES6 - how far can we go to build great websites without the need for Library/Framework X?</p> 
            </div>
           </div>

                <p data-reactid="155" class="info"><a data-reactid="156" href="/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citl73zll0cnsxi53rsc9r5f3">27 Sep 2016</a><span class="middot" data-reactid="157"> · </span>

                 <!-- react-text: 159 -->answer
                 <!-- /react-text --></p>
               </div>

              <div data-reactid="160" class="rightControls controlsSection">
               <span data-reactid="161"><a data-reactid="162" href="#" class="follow-button-profile userFollowBtn">
                 <svg data-reactid="163" viewbox="0 0 101.97 108.27" width="13px" height="13px">
                  <use data-reactid="164" xlink:href="#follow"></use>
                 </svg><span class="followText" data-reactid="165">Follow</span></a></span>
              </div>
             </div>
             <meta content="2016-09-27T08:02:54.586Z" itemprop="dateCreated" data-reactid="166">
             <meta content="https://hashnode.com/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citl73zll0cnsxi53rsc9r5f3" itemprop="url" data-reactid="167">
             <div data-reactid="168" class="response-stickers-container">
              <p data-reactid="169">
               <!-- react-text: 170 -->This 
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 171 -->answer
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 172 --> has received 
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 173 -->2
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 174 --> appreciation
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 175 -->s
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 176 -->.
               <!-- /react-text --></p>
              <ul class="inline-list badges-list" data-reactid="177">
               <li data-reactid="178"><a data-reactid="179" href="#" data-active-tab="appreciators"><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1447773026/badges/appr-7.png" data-reactid="180"><span class="badge-count" data-reactid="181">1</span><span class="badge-title" data-reactid="182">Spot On</span></a></li>
               <li data-reactid="183"><a data-reactid="184" href="#" data-active-tab="appreciators"><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1447773026/badges/appr-5.png" data-reactid="185"><span class="badge-count" data-reactid="186">1</span><span class="badge-title" data-reactid="187">1 Beer</span></a></li>
              </ul>
             </div>
             <div data-reactid="188" class="response-desc">
              <div data-reactid="189" itemprop="description">
               <p>Especially lately, I am ditching all JS frameworks in favor of CSS3 (animation, transition,...) and VanillaJS. I only use small libraries, like <a target="_blank" href="https://github.com/joewalnes/reconnecting-websocket">reconnecting-websockets.js</a>, which make my life easier. Why re-invent the wheel when I do not need an innovative solution but just something which works?</p> 
               <p>But careful there! I am not a professional front-end dev who builds the next Facebook. Depending on your project, things like Virtual Dom can make a huge difference, and when using Virtual Dom, you do need frameworks, like React; or HTML manipulation becomes tedious.</p> 
               <p>Another thing to look out for is big projects. We have Dart and TypeScript for a reason: To minimize stupid bugs. We are humans, so we have difficulties making sure that everything is exactly what we expect all the time. Though, given proficient developers, they will surely come up with an adequate solution in a timely fashion, written entirely in modern JS. But how many people could pull that off? What about mixed or loose teams?</p> 
               <p>So the bottomline is: We can go all the way with VanillaJS, but at some point, the performance becomes terrible or programming becomes tedious or we start making stupid bugs because we lose oversight, are missing knowledge or just have a bad day.</p> 
              </div>
             </div>
             <span data-reactid="190">
              <meta content="1" itemprop="downvoteCount" data-reactid="191">
              <meta content="20" itemprop="upvoteCount" data-reactid="192"></span>

              </div>
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
          </div>
          <div data-reactid="255">
           <div data-reactid="256" itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/answer">
            <div data-reactid="257" class="response-card" id="citlbl8yo0cuuey53m9afp3ch">
             <div data-reactid="258" class="response-header" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
              <div data-reactid="259" class="leftControls controlsSection">
               <a data-reactid="260" href="/@hugollm" class="userPic" data-username="hugollm"><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/w_70,h_70,c_thumb/v1493350648/ccga4mcelll8cv8jegxw_cropped.png" alt="" data-reactid="261"></a>
               <div data-reactid="262" class="userInfo">
                <meta content="Hugo Mota" itemprop="name" data-reactid="263">
                <meta content="/@hugollm" itemprop="sameAs" data-reactid="264">
                <meta content="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1493350648/ccga4mcelll8cv8jegxw_cropped.png" itemprop="image" data-reactid="265">
                <p data-reactid="266" class="name"><a data-reactid="267" href="/@hugollm" class="user-name" itemprop="url">Hugo Mota</a></p>
                <p data-reactid="268" class="info"><a data-reactid="269" href="/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citlbl8yo0cuuey53m9afp3ch">27 Sep 2016</a><span class="middot" data-reactid="270"> · </span>
                 <!-- react-text: 271 --> 
                 <!-- /react-text -->
                 <!-- react-text: 272 -->answer
                 <!-- /react-text --></p>
               </div>
              </div>
              <div data-reactid="273" class="rightControls controlsSection">
               <span data-reactid="274"><a data-reactid="275" href="#" class="follow-button-profile userFollowBtn">
                 <svg data-reactid="276" viewbox="0 0 101.97 108.27" width="13px" height="13px">
                  <use data-reactid="277" xlink:href="#follow"></use>
                 </svg><span class="followText" data-reactid="278">Follow</span></a></span>
              </div>
             </div>
             <meta content="2016-09-27T10:08:18.342Z" itemprop="dateCreated" data-reactid="279">
             <meta content="https://hashnode.com/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citlbl8yo0cuuey53m9afp3ch" itemprop="url" data-reactid="280">
             <div data-reactid="281" class="response-desc">
              <div data-reactid="282" itemprop="description">
               <p>Websites? Go for it. Javascript is very mature right now for simple tasks, you don't even need jquery for that anymore.</p> 
               <p>Applications? I wouldn't. DOM manipulation will bite you in the ass at no time. Even if you manage to pull it off, you'll probably end up skipping usability improvements because they will be too hard for the value they would aggregate.</p> 
               <p>I'm saying this because I currently have to deal with projects that are somewhat close to Vanilla JS. The developers carefully tried to organize things and make for a reasonable project. They are still a pain to maintain, and it's not the developers fault at all.</p> 
              </div>
             </div>
             <span data-reactid="283">
              <meta content="0" itemprop="downvoteCount" data-reactid="284">
              <meta content="7" itemprop="upvoteCount" data-reactid="285"></span>

          <div data-reactid="323">
           <div data-reactid="324" itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/answer">
            <div data-reactid="325" class="response-card" id="citm0v3oh0herxt53d8iygvnn">
             <div data-reactid="326" class="response-header" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
              <div data-reactid="327" class="leftControls controlsSection">
               <a data-reactid="328" href="/@mevrael" class="userPic" data-username="mevrael"><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/w_70,h_70,c_thumb/v1458939712/pyfmbtkvtyiadipdsj0a.jpg" alt="" data-reactid="329"></a>
               <div data-reactid="330" class="userInfo">
                <meta content="Mev-Rael" itemprop="name" data-reactid="331">
                <meta content="/@mevrael" itemprop="sameAs" data-reactid="332">
                <meta content="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1458939712/pyfmbtkvtyiadipdsj0a.jpg" itemprop="image" data-reactid="333">
                <p data-reactid="334" class="name"><a data-reactid="335" href="/@mevrael" class="user-name" itemprop="url">Mev-Rael</a></p>
                <p data-reactid="336" class="info"><a data-reactid="337" href="/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citm0v3oh0herxt53d8iygvnn">27 Sep 2016</a><span class="middot" data-reactid="338"> · </span>
                 <!-- react-text: 339 --> 
                 <!-- /react-text -->
                 <!-- react-text: 340 -->answer
                 <!-- /react-text --></p>
               </div>
              </div>
              <div data-reactid="341" class="rightControls controlsSection">
               <span data-reactid="342"><a data-reactid="343" href="#" class="follow-button-profile userFollowBtn">
                 <svg data-reactid="344" viewbox="0 0 101.97 108.27" width="13px" height="13px">
                  <use data-reactid="345" xlink:href="#follow"></use>
                 </svg><span class="followText" data-reactid="346">Follow</span></a></span>
              </div>
             </div>
             <meta content="2016-09-27T21:55:48.450Z" itemprop="dateCreated" data-reactid="347">
             <meta content="https://hashnode.com/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citm0v3oh0herxt53d8iygvnn" itemprop="url" data-reactid="348">
             <div data-reactid="349" class="response-stickers-container">
              <p data-reactid="350">
               <!-- react-text: 351 -->This 
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 352 -->answer
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 353 --> has received 
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 354 -->1
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 355 --> appreciation
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 356 -->
               <!-- /react-text -->
               <!-- react-text: 357 -->.
               <!-- /react-text --></p>
              <ul class="inline-list badges-list" data-reactid="358">
               <li data-reactid="359"><a data-reactid="360" href="#" data-active-tab="appreciators"><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1447773026/badges/appr-7.png" data-reactid="361"><span class="badge-count" data-reactid="362">1</span><span class="badge-title" data-reactid="363">Spot On</span></a></li>
              </ul>
             </div>
             <div data-reactid="364" class="response-desc">
              <div data-reactid="365" itemprop="description">
               <p>Thanks for invites to answer this question. For now I will just give a very short answer since the full one is very big. I am going to finish my article on Medium about Vanilla JS architecture in some weeks where I am going to explain a lot.</p> 
               <hr> 
               <h1 id="people-are-confusing-browser-environment-and-javascript-with-a-real-programming-languages-and-server-environments-">People are confusing Browser environment and JavaScript with a real programming languages and server environments.</h1> 
               <p>JavaScript is a scripting language - general Browser's API, it never was a full serious programming language and it shouldn't be. JS was invented to do a simple job - add dynamics to browser and allow not even an engineerers, but designers, just coders to "talk to browser". A bit later JS become a standard known as ECMA and most of the JS engines are written in C/C++/Java. In simple words - <strong>JavaScript itself already is a framework and JavaScript (ES6 with Web APIs) today is a very powerful browser's framework.</strong></p> 
               <p>On the other hand, real programming languages exists for general purpose and give you access to OS, processes, I/O and etc. They by default do not provide you any tools. If you need to parse a string which is HTML and build a DOM, you need to write your own solution (or to include a package which was anyway written by someone previously). In JavaScript you already have many of these packages included globally by default and you don't need to implement them yourself, you have access to client's window, document, images, links and many other stuff. Today there are a lot of modern Web APIs which allows you to send push notification, get acccess to microphone, camera, you can draw 3D games in canvas and do a lot of cool things. For example, most of JS users (developers) don't know basic algorithms in computer graphics, higher mathematics, data structures and a lot of other topics from Computer Science. That's why JS become so popular - because it is very simple and gives you a lot of built-in tools.</p> 
               <p>The reason why frameworks are needed in real programming languages and especially on back-end is, simply, because it's not the language's job to give you APIs.</p> 
               <p><strong>That's why JS frameworks are useless.</strong> Moreover, they just add extra abstraction and increase the code you should transfer to user from the server and <strong>in mobile age of the slow Internet, it is crticial.</strong> Why do I need to include a 50-500kb of JS which doesn't do anything? I can include a stand-alone library which will do a form validation, for example, and only for cost of 5kb. I can include another library and write a bit of custom codebase. <strong>At the end I may have full codebase which does a lot and still is much smaller then a framework which doesn't do anything.</strong></p> 
               <h1 id="libraries-can-and-should-be-used">Libraries can and should be used</h1> 
               <p>The reason why UNIX is so popular - because it is simple set of many small components, small programs, where each one is doing it small job and they all do not depend on each other. You probably have been using many of them in last week. Here is just a very small example of common ones: ls, cd, mkdir, rmdir, mv, cp, top, kill, man, ssh.</p> 
               <h1 id="some-myths-about-the-frameworks-and-vanilla-js">Some myths about the frameworks and Vanilla JS</h1> 
               <ol> 
                <li><strong>People are using frameworks because of 2 reasons: 1) they believe it will give them some magic and automatically write their app. 2nd reason is - marketing.</strong> One of the comments below proves it again. People believe in a myth that they need to use React to do a DOM manipulation. In modern society there is a problem - people think that they need X to do Y, e.g. I need a co-founder to start my idea, I need to use a framework to build a website, I need to look good to ask for something, etc. You don't need X to do Y, just do it. But let's go back to the React. There are no real proofs and noone can give precise numbers on how React solves that problem and what problem it actually tries to solve. React invented a virtual problem doesn't exists. Facebook news feed still lags but browsers crashes more today. I hadn't pressed Reset button on my PC for many years and some time ago I did it because of a browser.</li> 
                <li><strong>Myth - If you are not using framework you don't have an architecture and code is hard to maintain.</strong> Again in one answer below I see people are blaming Vanilla JS for unmaintainability. It IS engineer's fault not JS's if code is hard to maintain, simply, it means you have NO architecture. Well, the fact is the most projects and even small companies/startups don't have an architect and it's not engineer's job to maintain the architecture, however, each engineer is making small architecture decisions all the time. That's the real problem why most of codebases in most projects around the world is hard to maintain. Believe me my Vanilla JS code is simple as React and maybe even simpler. I do not reinvent the wheel, I have a very basic MVC adapted for browser.</li> 
                <li><strong>Myth - perfomance is bad.</strong> Vanilla JS is actually faster because of the obvious reasons. Anyway such microperfomance is evil. If code is slow, then again it is engineer's fault. I've seen people failed even using solid frameworks many times.</li> 
                <li><strong>Myth - hard to write a code and debug</strong> - Again it's not problem with JS. Use ES6 and some bundler like rollup, set up IDE, ESlint and other tools and you will have a lot of warnings and even errors during "compliation" if something is wrong in your code. <strong>But I would like to recommend something I've learned from a one designer many years ago</strong> when I was visiting her master class because it was free and I wasn't much interested in design itself. She once said - "Forget about Ctrl+Z / Undo / Eraser in your PhotoShop or any other tool. Always think like in a real life where there is impossible to undo a past. If you designed a logo and something went wrong - don't save a file, just start everything from the beginning again and do not repeat same mistake again". It teaches you the highest discipline and attention to smallest details. You always will have problems until you won't stop thinking that it can be undone anytime without loss. If you have done something, it's done, deal with it. Don't repeat it, plan better and control yourself more next time.</li> 
               </ol> 
               <hr> 
               <p>So yes, you can go very far with modern Vanilla JS and build complicated modern apps.</p> 
               <p>Finally at the end I want to remind every software engineer one of the core principles in software engineering which is also applied everywhere in the life - <a target="_blank" href="https://www.wikiwand.com/en/KISS_principle">KISS (Keep it simple, stupid)</a></p> 
               <blockquote> 
                <p>“Perfection is achieved not when there is nothing left to add, but when there is nothing left to take away” – Antoine de Saint-Exupery</p> 
               </blockquote> 
              </div>
             </div>
             <span data-reactid="366">
              <meta content="4" itemprop="downvoteCount" data-reactid="367">
              <meta content="3" itemprop="upvoteCount" data-reactid="368"></span>
             <div data-reactid="369" class="response-footer">
              <div data-reactid="370" class="left-section">
               <button class="footerAct upvote" data-reactid="371"><i class="mdi mdi-thumb-up-outline" data-reactid="372"></i><span class="btnText" data-reactid="373">3</span></button>
               <a data-reactid="374" href="#" class="footerAct replyAct">

                <!-- /react-text --><span class="countBadge" data-reactid="376">13</span></a>
              </div>
              <div data-reactid="377" class="RightActWrap">
               <span class="shareAct" data-reactid="378"><button class="footerAct shareBtn" data-reactid="379" title="Share">

                  <use data-reactid="381" xlink:href="#share-line"></use>
                 </svg><span class="shareText" data-reactid="382">Share</span></button></span>

              <div data-reactid="392" class="single-reply" id="reply-citmxuegs0metxi533b49a4j7" itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">
               <div data-reactid="393">
                <div data-reactid="394" class="reply-creator-wrapper">
                 <div data-reactid="395" class="reply-meta-header" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
                  <meta content="Marco Alka" itemprop="name" data-reactid="396">
                  <meta content="https://hashnode.com/@maruru" itemprop="sameAs" data-reactid="397">
                  <meta content="https://hashnode.com/@maruru" itemprop="url" data-reactid="398">
                  <meta content="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1469961782/if3shn8aspwcqlkpp9xu.jpg" itemprop="image" data-reactid="399">
                  <a data-reactid="400" href="/@maruru" class="reply-creator-img" data-username="maruru"><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/w_70,h_70,c_thumb/v1469961782/if3shn8aspwcqlkpp9xu.jpg" alt="" data-reactid="401"></a>
                  <p data-reactid="402" class="reply-creator-info"><a data-reactid="403" href="/@maruru" class="reply-creator">Marco Alka</a><span class="middot" data-reactid="404"> · </span><a data-reactid="405" href="#" class="replyDate">
                    <!-- react-text: 406 -->28 Sep 2016
                    <!-- /react-text -->
                    <meta content="2016-09-28T13:19:03.102Z" itemprop="datePublished" data-reactid="407"></a></p>
                 </div>
                </div>
                <div data-reactid="408" class="reply-text-content" itemprop="description">
                 <p><a href="/@mevrael" class="user-mention" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">@mevrael</a></p> 
                 <blockquote> 
                  <p>So again what React gives me? I already have [..]</p> 
                 </blockquote> 
                 <p>It's OK if you do not need it. Just do not generalize your projects and way of working.</p> 
                 <blockquote> 
                  <p>In the link you provided Eich says what I have written. How my statement is false or are you always reading the words and not trying to understand the meaning altogether?</p> 
                 </blockquote> 
                 <p>No. You said that JavaScript has it's name because <code>Java was so popular and everyone was crazy.</code> (which is a completely random reason), while Eich said that <code>the idea was to make it a complementary scripting language to go with Java</code> (which is a very valid reason). The difference might seem subtle, but the resulting statements are very contrary!</p> 
                 <blockquote> 
                  <p>I am not going to keep discussion about what is a framework</p> 
                 </blockquote> 
                 <p>Why not finish it with a solid quotation, then? A definition for a framework is nothing scientific at all. It's just a definition. For example <a target="_blank" href="http://www.riehle.org/computer-science/research/dissertation/diss-a4.pdf">Dirk Riehle of Universität Hamburg submitted a dissertation to the SWISS FEDERAL INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY ZURICH</a>, in which he defines a software framework as:</p> 
                 <blockquote> 
                  <p>[A software framework] leaves enough room for customization to solve a particular problem in the application domain. Developers who apply a framework reuse its design and implementation. They do so to solve an application problem that falls into the domain modeled by the framework. By reusing the design, application developers customize a (hopefully) well-understood software architecture to their own specific application problem.</p> 
                 </blockquote> 
                 <p>Which means that someone writes a piece of software which solves a problem and can be extended/customized by application code, which has the certain problem which is solved by the framework. This means that a framework is a skeleton for the actual application or solution.</p> 
                 <blockquote> 
                  <p>Instead of including [many frameworks] you can simply include a 2kb stand-alone component [..]</p> 
                 </blockquote> 
                 <p>Yeah, let's agree on that! I think that's the one advice which we really need when we talk about VanillaJS :)</p> 
                </div>
                <ul class="reply-action" data-reactid="409">
                 <li data-reactid="410"><a data-reactid="411" href="#" class="replyUpvoteBtn"><i class="mdi mdi-thumb-up-outline" data-reactid="412"></i>
                   <!-- react-text: 413 --> 
                   <!-- /react-text -->
                   <!-- react-text: 414 -->1
                   <!-- /react-text --></a></li>
                </ul>
               </div>
              </div>

                     <div data-reactid="428" data-contents="true">
                      <div data-reactid="429" class="lbgWvolvc8ZRJwK4L3Fx-" data-block="true" data-editor="ebl6n" data-offset-key="e3t71-0-0">
                       <div data-reactid="430" class="public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="e3t71-0-0">

          <div data-reactid="439">
           <div data-reactid="440" itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/answer">
            <div data-reactid="441" class="response-card" id="citu4l6gz00u1vj536g972wf4">
             <div data-reactid="442" class="response-header" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
              <div data-reactid="443" class="leftControls controlsSection">
               <a data-reactid="444" href="/@tracker1" class="userPic" data-username="tracker1"><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/w_70,h_70,c_thumb/v1457055566/mjjul9mc8bqnt9x1mdv7.jpg" alt="" data-reactid="445"></a>
               <div data-reactid="446" class="userInfo">
                <meta content="Michael J. Ryan" itemprop="name" data-reactid="447">
                <meta content="/@tracker1" itemprop="sameAs" data-reactid="448">
                <meta content="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1457055566/mjjul9mc8bqnt9x1mdv7.jpg" itemprop="image" data-reactid="449">
                <p data-reactid="450" class="name"><a data-reactid="451" href="/@tracker1" class="user-name" itemprop="url">Michael J. Ryan</a></p>
                <p data-reactid="452" class="info"><a data-reactid="453" href="/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citu4l6gz00u1vj536g972wf4">3 Oct 2016</a><span class="middot" data-reactid="454"> · </span>
                 <!-- react-text: 455 --> 
                 <!-- /react-text -->
                 <!-- react-text: 456 -->answer
                 <!-- /react-text --></p>
               </div>
              </div>
              <div data-reactid="457" class="rightControls controlsSection">
               <span data-reactid="458"><a data-reactid="459" href="#" class="follow-button-profile userFollowBtn">
                 <svg data-reactid="460" viewbox="0 0 101.97 108.27" width="13px" height="13px">
                  <use data-reactid="461" xlink:href="#follow"></use>
                 </svg><span class="followText" data-reactid="462">Follow</span></a></span>
              </div>
             </div>
             <meta content="2016-10-03T14:02:13.380Z" itemprop="dateCreated" data-reactid="463">
             <meta content="https://hashnode.com/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citu4l6gz00u1vj536g972wf4" itemprop="url" data-reactid="464">
             <div data-reactid="465" class="response-desc">
              <div data-reactid="466" itemprop="description">
               <p>As long as you are using some form of module bundler (webpack/browserify/rollup, etc), you can go a really long way with relatively plain JS... The only reason I mention using a bundler is it allows you to write your code in discrete modules.</p> 
               <p>As it is, you can go a very long way. Also, it makes it easier to add micro libraries via npm after you've done this, which allows you to stay very close to vanilla while still being able to support a growing codebase.</p> 
              </div>
             </div>
             <span data-reactid="467">
              <meta content="0" itemprop="downvoteCount" data-reactid="468">
              <meta content="3" itemprop="upvoteCount" data-reactid="469"></span>
             <div data-reactid="470" class="response-footer">
              <div data-reactid="471" class="left-section">

                <!-- /react-text --></a>

          <div data-reactid="507">
           <div data-reactid="508" itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/answer">
            <div data-reactid="509" class="response-card" id="citnhjri00c3l34532oz4x15c">
             <div data-reactid="510" class="response-header" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
              <div data-reactid="511" class="leftControls controlsSection">
               <a data-reactid="512" href="/@luord" class="userPic" data-username="luord"><img src="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/w_70,h_70,c_thumb/v1475091663/gamzffdyrsn9piytjxdw.jpg" alt="" data-reactid="513"></a>
               <div data-reactid="514" class="userInfo">
                <meta content="Luis Orduz" itemprop="name" data-reactid="515">
                <meta content="/@luord" itemprop="sameAs" data-reactid="516">
                <meta content="https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1475091663/gamzffdyrsn9piytjxdw.jpg" itemprop="image" data-reactid="517">
                <p data-reactid="518" class="name"><a data-reactid="519" href="/@luord" class="user-name" itemprop="url">Luis Orduz</a></p>
                <p data-reactid="520" class="info"><a data-reactid="521" href="/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citnhjri00c3l34532oz4x15c">28 Sep 2016</a><span class="middot" data-reactid="522"> · </span>
                 <!-- react-text: 523 --> 
                 <!-- /react-text -->
                 <!-- react-text: 524 -->answer
                 <!-- /react-text --></p>
               </div>
              </div>
              <div data-reactid="525" class="rightControls controlsSection">
               <span data-reactid="526"><a data-reactid="527" href="#" class="follow-button-profile userFollowBtn">
                 <svg data-reactid="528" viewbox="0 0 101.97 108.27" width="13px" height="13px">
                  <use data-reactid="529" xlink:href="#follow"></use>
                 </svg><span class="followText" data-reactid="530">Follow</span></a></span>
              </div>
             </div>
             <meta content="2016-09-28T22:30:39.096Z" itemprop="dateCreated" data-reactid="531">
             <meta content="https://hashnode.com/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citnhjri00c3l34532oz4x15c" itemprop="url" data-reactid="532">
             <div data-reactid="533" class="response-desc">
              <div data-reactid="534" itemprop="description">
               <p>Pretty far, indeed.</p> 
               <p>A company I worked in had their entire frontend codebase written in in-house javascript. JQuery was the only external library linked but I never actually found where it was being used.</p> 
               <p>It was quite a lot of stuff: a full, feature-packed SOA client, something I would call an ORM even though it wasn't exactly it, a standard library of utilities and, more interestingly, a visual styling IDE for creating responsive websites based on tiling (like webflow), etc.</p> 
               <p>Yeah, there were no tests and massive refactoring could've gone a long way, besides changing a few idiosyncrasies (such as replacing SOA for full-featured REST among other stuff). But that they managed to build all that from scratch and it, mostly, worked I find a bit impressive.</p> 
               <p>The company eventually went under but the reason was not their technology.</p> 
               <p>All of that taught me to always think very carefully before deciding to use external libraries or full-featured frameworks, as I know that we can work without them and have worked like that already. I still reuse a lot, but I do so critically and will write my own code confidently if I feel that that will save me time and pain.</p> 
              </div>
             </div>
             <span data-reactid="535">
              <meta content="0" itemprop="downvoteCount" data-reactid="536">
              <meta content="3" itemprop="upvoteCount" data-reactid="537"></span>

             <meta content="2016-09-27T12:57:29.401Z" itemprop="dateCreated" data-reactid="599">
             <meta content="https://hashnode.com/post/how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js-citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn/answer/citlhmtkj0dx1ey53dju82ffg" itemprop="url" data-reactid="600">
             <div data-reactid="601" class="response-desc">
              <div data-reactid="602" itemprop="description">
               <p>I've built a complete phonegap application in 2014 with vanilla js (ES5) and just CSS + html5 even with canvas fireworks animations based on jack rugiles code pen examples + local storage + workers. I totally agree with <a href="/@maruru" class="user-mention" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">@maruru</a> as long as the codebase remains small it's doesn't really matter.</p> 
              </div>
             </div>

               </div>
               <div data-reactid="691" class="reply-editor-wrap">
                <div data-reactid="692" class="_3r5AlqSQ5xeBPo-eQ_-GSY _923WTu-Dit9zrjNDrtIZZ">
                 <!-- react-empty: 693 -->
                 <div data-reactid="694" class="WcmEsSxvtdmjppeQCvd0w reply-textarea">
                  <div data-reactid="695" class="DraftEditor-root">
                   <div data-reactid="696" class="public-DraftEditorPlaceholder-root">
                    <div data-reactid="697" class="public-DraftEditorPlaceholder-inner" id="placeholder-c16gp">
                     Write a reply...
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <div data-reactid="698" class="DraftEditor-editorContainer">
                    <div data-reactid="699" class="public-DraftEditor-content" aria-describedby="placeholder-c16gp" contenteditable="true" role="textbox" spellcheck="true" style="outline:none;white-space:pre-wrap;word-wrap:break-word">
                     <div data-reactid="700" data-contents="true">
                      <div data-reactid="701" class="lbgWvolvc8ZRJwK4L3Fx-" data-block="true" data-editor="c16gp" data-offset-key="6tv38-0-0">
                       <div data-reactid="702" class="public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="6tv38-0-0">
                        <span data-offset-key="6tv38-0-0" data-reactid="703"><br data-text="true" data-reactid="704"></span>
                       </div>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </div>
               </div>
              </div>
              <div data-reactid="705" class="reply-act-wrap">

               <p>Of course, we can do everything without the frameworks. </p>

Area, California&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:17,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;577ff0cb16a33191db0430a9&quot;},&quot;cuid&quot;:&quot;citkpyo7w0amxxi53n97yiqbn&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;how-far-can-you-go-with-vanilla-js&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;How far can you go with Vanilla JS?&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;question&quot;,&quot;url&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;labelsByNodes&quot;:{&quot;labels&quot;:[]},&quot;__v&quot;:20,&quot;dateUpdated&quot;:&quot;2016-09-27T06:35:25.810Z&quot;,&quot;followersCount&quot;:9,&quot;bookmarkedIn&quot;:[],&quot;hasReward&quot;:false,&quot;publication&quot;:{&quot;name&quot;:&quot;None&quot;,&quot;slug&quot;:&quot;none&quot;},&quot;isPublication&quot;:false,&quot;numCollapsed&quot;:0,&quot;duplicatePosts&quot;:[],&quot;isDelisted&quot;:false,&quot;inviters&quot;:[],&quot;answeredByTarget&quot;:false,&quot;isEngaging&quot;:false,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;followers&quot;:[&quot;577ff0cb16a33191db0430a9&quot;,&quot;57e83e232fc775432c0eed26&quot;,&quot;570cc097a813d4ceb0550fb5&quot;,&quot;54b81b237393d8e81463c55c&quot;,&quot;56adc4a383cf68e027c26b84&quot;,&quot;56f5a72f9625fc49458f85f2&quot;,&quot;57e9ff7355544e5132a4d6b4&quot;,&quot;56ee78d5bcca2d711e191e38&quot;,&quot;580c51c1ed2f5e79b7917be2&quot;],&quot;responseCount&quot;:8,&quot;questionReplies&quot;:[],&quot;responses&quot;:[{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;Especially lately, I am ditching all JS frameworks in favor of CSS3 (animation, transition,...) and VanillaJS. I only use small libraries, like &lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;https://github.com/joewalnes/reconnecting-websocket\\&quot;&gt;reconnecting-websockets.js&lt;/a&gt;, which make my life easier. Why re-invent the wheel when I do not need an innovative solution but just something which works?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;But careful there! I am not a professional front-end dev who builds the next Facebook. Depending on your project, things like Virtual Dom can make a huge difference, and when using Virtual Dom, you do need frameworks, like React; or HTML manipulation becomes tedious.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Another thing to look out for is big projects. We have Dart and TypeScript for a reason: To minimize stupid bugs. We are humans, so we have difficulties making sure that everything is exactly what we expect all the time. Though, given proficient developers, they will surely come up with an adequate solution in a timely fashion, written entirely in modern JS. But how many people could pull that off? What about mixed or loose teams?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;So the bottomline is: We can go all the way with VanillaJS, but at some point, the performance becomes terrible or programming becomes tedious or we start making stupid bugs because we lose oversight, are missing knowledge or just have a bad day.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;Especially lately, I am ditching all JS frameworks in favor of CSS3 (animation, transition,...) and VanillaJS. I only use small libraries, like [reconnecting-websockets.js](https://github.com/joewalnes/reconnecting-websocket), which make my life easier. Why re-invent the wheel when I do not need an innovative solution but just something which works?\\n\\nBut careful there! I am not a professional front-end dev who builds the next Facebook. Depending on your project, things like Virtual Dom can make a huge difference, and when using Virtual Dom, you do need frameworks, like React; or HTML manipulation becomes tedious.\\n\\nAnother thing to look out for is big projects. We have Dart and TypeScript for a reason: To minimize stupid bugs. We are humans, so we have difficulties making sure that everything is exactly what we expect all the time. Though, given proficient developers, they will surely come up with an adequate solution in a timely fashion, written entirely in modern JS. But how many people could pull that off? What about mixed or loose teams?\\n\\nSo the bottomline is: We can go all the way with VanillaJS, but at some point, the performance becomes terrible or programming becomes tedious or we start making stupid bugs because we lose oversight, are missing knowledge or just have a bad day.&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;570cc097a813d4ceb0550fb5&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;maruru&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Marco Alka&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1469961782/if3shn8aspwcqlkpp9xu.jpg&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Software Engineer, E2.0 Evangelist, Hobby Game Developer&quot;,&quot;coverImage&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1469962307/kqizbhn4z8j6onrdkmuy.jpg&quot;,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[],&quot;totalUpvotesReceived&quot;:3165,&quot;appreciations&quot;:[{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5aba&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ac31c0acdcb6810ec2d83b&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:24},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab8&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ac31b8acdcb6810ec2d838&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:15},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ac0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57a050cee6e9c21356b91927&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:34},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abf&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;577a06bfa1ac2f52aea75708&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:34},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;576ee9faf95d0ee3e2d75c80&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:106},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abb&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5767e0ada841f03b9338c561&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:44},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abe&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5764470ca841f03b9338c419&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:68},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abc&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;575e9407ed4fa39df4f9af8a&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:43},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab9&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;570f4e11a918e8a3026ebab6&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:9}],&quot;dateJoined&quot;:&quot;2016-04-12T09:32:07.287Z&quot;,&quot;socialMedia&quot;:{&quot;linkedin&quot;:&quot;https://www.linkedin.com/in/marco-alka-678825a8&quot;,&quot;stackoverflow&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;google&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;facebook&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;twitter&quot;:&quot;https://twitter.com/minecrawlerx&quot;,&quot;github&quot;:&quot;https://github.com/minecrawler&quot;,&quot;website&quot;:&quot;https://marco-alka.de&quot;},&quot;storiesCreated&quot;:[&quot;595f89a27235df722d9e4b54&quot;,&quot;5953a468e69695c0e87436e5&quot;,&quot;58718f8a4bd824eaa1272b89&quot;,&quot;581adbbe6c2fec00ae8c0c6c&quot;,&quot;58134bf9cc3446062c875a30&quot;,&quot;57d170a7f5e82d1d7e53de15&quot;,&quot;57c6baf7fa91cd4e941da9ab&quot;,&quot;57c43cc8cb80370904fc5c4d&quot;],&quot;numFollowing&quot;:23,&quot;numFollowers&quot;:1066,&quot;location&quot;:&quot;GERMANY&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:377,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;570cc097a813d4ceb0550fb5&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citl73zll0cnsxi53rsc9r5f3&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ea27ae97eba84632db55d8&quot;,&quot;bookmarkedIn&quot;:[],&quot;isRewardWinner&quot;:false,&quot;totalBadgesAwarded&quot;:2,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[{&quot;badge&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abe&quot;,&quot;image&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1447773026/badges/appr-7.png&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;target&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;badge.response&quot;,&quot;displayName&quot;:&quot;Spot On&quot;,&quot;__v&quot;:0},&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57eafeb1e40cc4ca39a411d0&quot;,&quot;from&quot;:[&quot;56f6b05384a27c6e6dee9583&quot;]},{&quot;badge&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abc&quot;,&quot;image&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1447773026/badges/appr-5.png&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;1beer&quot;,&quot;type&quot;:&quot;badge.response&quot;,&quot;displayName&quot;:&quot;1 Beer&quot;,&quot;__v&quot;:0},&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57eaacd297eba84632db575f&quot;,&quot;from&quot;:[&quot;577ff0cb16a33191db0430a9&quot;]}],&quot;isCollapsed&quot;:false,&quot;downvotes&quot;:1,&quot;upvotes&quot;:20,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-27T08:02:54.586Z&quot;,&quot;popularity&quot;:0.8036,&quot;replies&quot;:[{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;microlibs FTW!&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;microlibs FTW!&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5790e4d14778841e68c2052e&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;hipkiss91&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Hipkiss&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1469113717/wlobxnxtzunsur2ejnpf.png&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Problem Solver @ a start-up&quot;,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[],&quot;totalUpvotesReceived&quot;:961,&quot;appreciations&quot;:[{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab8&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;584ffde759fd1394c809c8be&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:1},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5aba&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;58214b27040f8ce78887ba51&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:4},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abf&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;581e355b4d19a20289ad3d38&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:7},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;581a376aae2865e5ada27fc3&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:16},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abc&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57daa011f72dd3705c160684&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:9},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abe&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57b5c97dcb7324cfcb5401f2&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:16},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ac0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57b3d7505c04a5c09d4588d3&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:10},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abb&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;579e37420ac23d4188b47124&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:10},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab9&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;579e373e019fa036887f8185&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:2}],&quot;dateJoined&quot;:&quot;2016-07-21T15:05:53.226Z&quot;,&quot;socialMedia&quot;:{&quot;linkedin&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;stackoverflow&quot;:&quot;https://stackoverflow.com/users/4026523/hipkiss&quot;,&quot;google&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;facebook&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;twitter&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;github&quot;:&quot;https://github.com/hipkiss91&quot;,&quot;website&quot;:&quot;&quot;},&quot;storiesCreated&quot;:[&quot;58232f1b040f8ce78887bc5a&quot;],&quot;numFollowing&quot;:20,&quot;numFollowers&quot;:522,&quot;location&quot;:&quot;UK&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:75,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;5790e4d14778841e68c2052e&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citl94ve00cfxfp53l1gbq6kq&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ea34f728f98be5393fa022&quot;,&quot;upvotes&quot;:1,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-27T08:59:35.016Z&quot;}],&quot;id&quot;:&quot;57ea27ae97eba84632db55d8&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;Websites? Go for it. Javascript is very mature right now for simple tasks, you don&amp;#39;t even need jquery for that anymore.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Applications? I wouldn&amp;#39;t. DOM manipulation will bite you in the ass at no time. Even if you manage to pull it off, you&amp;#39;ll probably end up skipping usability improvements because they will be too hard for the value they would aggregate.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I&amp;#39;m saying this because I currently have to deal with projects that are somewhat close to Vanilla JS. The developers carefully tried to organize things and make for a reasonable project. They are still a pain to maintain, and it&amp;#39;s not the developers fault at all.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;Websites? Go for it. Javascript is very mature right now for simple tasks, you don&#39;t even need jquery for that anymore.\\n\\nApplications? I wouldn&#39;t. DOM manipulation will bite you in the ass at no time. Even if you manage to pull it off, you&#39;ll probably end up skipping usability improvements because they will be too hard for the value they would aggregate.\\n\\nI&#39;m saying this because I currently have to deal with projects that are somewhat close to Vanilla JS. The developers carefully tried to organize things and make for a reasonable project. They are still a pain to maintain, and it&#39;s not the developers fault at all.&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57884a1e16a33191db0437b4&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;hugollm&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Hugo Mota&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1493350648/ccga4mcelll8cv8jegxw_cropped.png&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Code Hero&quot;,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[],&quot;totalUpvotesReceived&quot;:192,&quot;appreciations&quot;:[{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ac0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;579183dd7bcf1160974dd828&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:1},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abc&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;578e61eb5460288cdeb6f1d5&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:4},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;578ac3924707d0cd1f85ff54&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:6},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abe&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5789eb55bf4bc726ca6491e0&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:3},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abb&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5789e771f490149ffb3c776e&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:2}],&quot;dateJoined&quot;:&quot;2016-07-15T02:27:42.316Z&quot;,&quot;socialMedia&quot;:{&quot;linkedin&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;stackoverflow&quot;:&quot;http://stackoverflow.com/users/434293/hugo-leonardo&quot;,&quot;google&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;facebook&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;twitter&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;github&quot;:&quot;https://github.com/hugollm&quot;,&quot;website&quot;:&quot;&quot;},&quot;storiesCreated&quot;:[],&quot;numFollowing&quot;:8,&quot;numFollowers&quot;:66,&quot;location&quot;:&quot;Montes Claros - State of Minas&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:16,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;57884a1e16a33191db0437b4&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citlbl8yo0cuuey53m9afp3ch&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ea4512e40cc4ca39a41083&quot;,&quot;bookmarkedIn&quot;:[],&quot;isRewardWinner&quot;:false,&quot;totalBadgesAwarded&quot;:0,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[],&quot;isCollapsed&quot;:false,&quot;downvotes&quot;:0,&quot;upvotes&quot;:7,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-27T10:08:18.342Z&quot;,&quot;popularity&quot;:0.7559,&quot;replies&quot;:[],&quot;id&quot;:&quot;57ea4512e40cc4ca39a41083&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;Thanks for invites to answer this question. For now I will just give a very short answer since the full one is very big. I am going to finish my article on Medium about Vanilla JS architecture in some weeks where I am going to explain a lot.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;hr&gt;\\n&lt;h1 id=\\&quot;people-are-confusing-browser-environment-and-javascript-with-a-real-programming-languages-and-server-environments-\\&quot;&gt;People are confusing Browser environment and JavaScript with a real programming languages and server environments.&lt;/h1&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;JavaScript is a scripting language - general Browser&amp;#39;s API, it never was a full serious programming language and it shouldn&amp;#39;t be. JS was invented to do a simple job - add dynamics to browser and allow not even an engineerers, but designers, just coders to &amp;quot;talk to browser&amp;quot;. A bit later JS become a standard known as ECMA and most of the JS engines are written in C/C++/Java. In simple words - &lt;strong&gt;JavaScript itself already is a framework and JavaScript (ES6 with Web APIs) today is a very powerful browser&amp;#39;s framework.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;On the other hand, real programming languages exists for general purpose and give you access to OS, processes, I/O and etc. They by default do not provide you any tools. If you need to parse a string which is HTML and build a DOM, you need to write your own solution (or to include a package which was anyway written by someone previously). In JavaScript you already have many of these packages included globally by default and you don&amp;#39;t need to implement them yourself, you have access to client&amp;#39;s window, document, images, links and many other stuff. Today there are a lot of modern Web APIs which allows you to send push notification, get acccess to microphone, camera, you can draw 3D games in canvas and do a lot of cool things. For example, most of JS users (developers) don&amp;#39;t know basic algorithms in computer graphics, higher mathematics, data structures and a lot of other topics from Computer Science. That&amp;#39;s why JS become so popular - because it is very simple and gives you a lot of built-in tools.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;The reason why frameworks are needed in real programming languages and especially on back-end is, simply, because it&amp;#39;s not the language&amp;#39;s job to give you APIs.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;That&amp;#39;s why JS frameworks are useless.&lt;/strong&gt; Moreover, they just add extra abstraction and increase the code you should transfer to user from the server and &lt;strong&gt;in mobile age of the slow Internet, it is crticial.&lt;/strong&gt; Why do I need to include a 50-500kb of JS which doesn&amp;#39;t do anything? I can include a stand-alone library which will do a form validation, for example, and only for cost of 5kb. I can include another library and write a bit of custom codebase. &lt;strong&gt;At the end I may have full codebase which does a lot and still is much smaller then a framework which doesn&amp;#39;t do anything.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;h1 id=\\&quot;libraries-can-and-should-be-used\\&quot;&gt;Libraries can and should be used&lt;/h1&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;The reason why UNIX is so popular - because it is simple set of many small components, small programs, where each one is doing it small job and they all do not depend on each other. You probably have been using many of them in last week. Here is just a very small example of common ones: ls, cd, mkdir, rmdir, mv, cp, top, kill, man, ssh.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;h1 id=\\&quot;some-myths-about-the-frameworks-and-vanilla-js\\&quot;&gt;Some myths about the frameworks and Vanilla JS&lt;/h1&gt;\\n&lt;ol&gt;\\n&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;People are using frameworks because of 2 reasons: 1) they believe it will give them some magic and automatically write their app. 2nd reason is - marketing.&lt;/strong&gt; One of the comments below proves it again. People believe in a myth that they need to use React to do a DOM manipulation. In modern society there is a problem - people think that they need X to do Y, e.g. I need a co-founder to start my idea, I need to use a framework to build a website, I need to look good to ask for something, etc. You don&amp;#39;t need X to do Y, just do it. But let&amp;#39;s go back to the React. There are no real proofs and noone can give precise numbers on how React solves that problem and what problem it actually tries to solve. React invented a virtual problem doesn&amp;#39;t exists. Facebook news feed still lags but browsers crashes more today. I hadn&amp;#39;t pressed Reset button on my PC for many years and some time ago I did it because of a browser.&lt;/li&gt;\\n&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Myth - If you are not using framework you don&amp;#39;t have an architecture and code is hard to maintain.&lt;/strong&gt; Again in one answer below I see people are blaming Vanilla JS for unmaintainability. It IS engineer&amp;#39;s fault not JS&amp;#39;s if code is hard to maintain, simply, it means you have NO architecture. Well, the fact is the most projects and even small companies/startups don&amp;#39;t have an architect and it&amp;#39;s not engineer&amp;#39;s job to maintain the architecture, however, each engineer is making small architecture decisions all the time. That&amp;#39;s the real problem why most of codebases in most projects around the world is hard to maintain. Believe me my Vanilla JS code is simple as React and maybe even simpler. I do not reinvent the wheel, I have a very basic MVC adapted for browser.&lt;/li&gt;\\n&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Myth - perfomance is bad.&lt;/strong&gt; Vanilla JS is actually faster because of the obvious reasons. Anyway such microperfomance is evil. If code is slow, then again it is engineer&amp;#39;s fault. I&amp;#39;ve seen people failed even using solid frameworks many times.&lt;/li&gt;\\n&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Myth - hard to write a code and debug&lt;/strong&gt; - Again it&amp;#39;s not problem with JS. Use ES6 and some bundler like rollup, set up IDE, ESlint and other tools and you will have a lot of warnings and even errors during &amp;quot;compliation&amp;quot; if something is wrong in your code. &lt;strong&gt;But I would like to recommend something I&amp;#39;ve learned from a one designer many years ago&lt;/strong&gt; when I was visiting her master class because it was free and I wasn&amp;#39;t much interested in design itself. She once said - &amp;quot;Forget about Ctrl+Z / Undo / Eraser in your PhotoShop or any other tool. Always think like in a real life where there is impossible to undo a past. If you designed a logo and something went wrong - don&amp;#39;t save a file, just start everything from the beginning again and do not repeat same mistake again&amp;quot;. It teaches you the highest discipline and attention to smallest details. You always will have problems until you won&amp;#39;t stop thinking that it can be undone anytime without loss. If you have done something, it&amp;#39;s done, deal with it. Don&amp;#39;t repeat it, plan better and control yourself more next time.&lt;/li&gt;\\n&lt;/ol&gt;\\n&lt;hr&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;So yes, you can go very far with modern Vanilla JS and build complicated modern apps.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Finally at the end I want to remind every software engineer one of the core principles in software engineering which is also applied everywhere in the life - &lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;https://www.wikiwand.com/en/KISS_principle\\&quot;&gt;KISS (Keep it simple, stupid)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;“Perfection is achieved not when there is nothing left to add, but when there is nothing left to take away” – Antoine de Saint-Exupery&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;Thanks for invites to answer this question. For now I will just give a very short answer since the full one is very big. I am going to finish my article on Medium about Vanilla JS architecture in some weeks where I am going to explain a lot.\\n\\n---\\n\\n# People are confusing Browser environment and JavaScript with a real programming languages and server environments.\\n\\nJavaScript is a scripting language - general Browser&#39;s API, it never was a full serious programming language and it shouldn&#39;t be. JS was invented to do a simple job - add dynamics to browser and allow not even an engineerers, but designers, just coders to \\&quot;talk to browser\\&quot;. A bit later JS become a standard known as ECMA and most of the JS engines are written in C/C++/Java. In simple words - **JavaScript itself already is a framework and JavaScript (ES6 with Web APIs) today is a very powerful browser&#39;s framework.**\\n\\nOn the other hand, real programming languages exists for general purpose and give you access to OS, processes, I/O and etc. They by default do not provide you any tools. If you need to parse a string which is HTML and build a DOM, you need to write your own solution (or to include a package which was anyway written by someone previously). In JavaScript you already have many of these packages included globally by default and you don&#39;t need to implement them yourself, you have access to client&#39;s window, document, images, links and many other stuff. Today there are a lot of modern Web APIs which allows you to send push notification, get acccess to microphone, camera, you can draw 3D games in canvas and do a lot of cool things. For example, most of JS users (developers) don&#39;t know basic algorithms in computer graphics, higher mathematics, data structures and a lot of other topics from Computer Science. That&#39;s why JS become so popular - because it is very simple and gives you a lot of built-in tools.\\n\\nThe reason why frameworks are needed in real programming languages and especially on back-end is, simply, because it&#39;s not the language&#39;s job to give you APIs.\\n\\n**That&#39;s why JS frameworks are useless.** Moreover, they just add extra abstraction and increase the code you should transfer to user from the server and **in mobile age of the slow Internet, it is crticial.** Why do I need to include a 50-500kb of JS which doesn&#39;t do anything? I can include a stand-alone library which will do a form validation, for example, and only for cost of 5kb. I can include another library and write a bit of custom codebase. **At the end I may have full codebase which does a lot and still is much smaller then a framework which doesn&#39;t do anything.**\\n\\n\\n\\n# Libraries can and should be used\\n\\nThe reason why UNIX is so popular - because it is simple set of many small components, small programs, where each one is doing it small job and they all do not depend on each other. You probably have been using many of them in last week. Here is just a very small example of common ones: ls, cd, mkdir, rmdir, mv, cp, top, kill, man, ssh.\\n\\n\\n\\n# Some myths about the frameworks and Vanilla JS\\n\\n1. **People are using frameworks because of 2 reasons: 1) they believe it will give them some magic and automatically write their app. 2nd reason is - marketing.** One of the comments below proves it again. People believe in a myth that they need to use React to do a DOM manipulation. In modern society there is a problem - people think that they need X to do Y, e.g. I need a co-founder to start my idea, I need to use a framework to build a website, I need to look good to ask for something, etc. You don&#39;t need X to do Y, just do it. But let&#39;s go back to the React. There are no real proofs and noone can give precise numbers on how React solves that problem and what problem it actually tries to solve. React invented a virtual problem doesn&#39;t exists. Facebook news feed still lags but browsers crashes more today. I hadn&#39;t pressed Reset button on my PC for many years and some time ago I did it because of a browser.\\n2. **Myth - If you are not using framework you don&#39;t have an architecture and code is hard to maintain.** Again in one answer below I see people are blaming Vanilla JS for unmaintainability. It IS engineer&#39;s fault not JS&#39;s if code is hard to maintain, simply, it means you have NO architecture. Well, the fact is the most projects and even small companies/startups don&#39;t have an architect and it&#39;s not engineer&#39;s job to maintain the architecture, however, each engineer is making small architecture decisions all the time. That&#39;s the real problem why most of codebases in most projects around the world is hard to maintain. Believe me my Vanilla JS code is simple as React and maybe even simpler. I do not reinvent the wheel, I have a very basic MVC adapted for browser.\\n3. **Myth - perfomance is bad.** Vanilla JS is actually faster because of the obvious reasons. Anyway such microperfomance is evil. If code is slow, then again it is engineer&#39;s fault. I&#39;ve seen people failed even using solid frameworks many times.\\n4. **Myth - hard to write a code and debug** - Again it&#39;s not problem with JS. Use ES6 and some bundler like rollup, set up IDE, ESlint and other tools and you will have a lot of warnings and even errors during \\&quot;compliation\\&quot; if something is wrong in your code. **But I would like to recommend something I&#39;ve learned from a one designer many years ago** when I was visiting her master class because it was free and I wasn&#39;t much interested in design itself. She once said - \\&quot;Forget about Ctrl+Z / Undo / Eraser in your PhotoShop or any other tool. Always think like in a real life where there is impossible to undo a past. If you designed a logo and something went wrong - don&#39;t save a file, just start everything from the beginning again and do not repeat same mistake again\\&quot;. It teaches you the highest discipline and attention to smallest details. You always will have problems until you won&#39;t stop thinking that it can be undone anytime without loss. If you have done something, it&#39;s done, deal with it. Don&#39;t repeat it, plan better and control yourself more next time.\\n\\n---\\n\\nSo yes, you can go very far with modern Vanilla JS and build complicated modern apps.\\n\\nFinally at the end I want to remind every software engineer one of the core principles in software engineering which is also applied everywhere in the life - [KISS (Keep it simple, stupid)](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/KISS_principle)\\n\\n&gt; “Perfection is achieved not when there is nothing left to add, but when there is nothing left to take away” – Antoine de Saint-Exupery&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;56f5a72f9625fc49458f85f2&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;mevrael&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Mev-Rael&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1458939712/pyfmbtkvtyiadipdsj0a.jpg&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Leader, AI Architect at Bunny AI and creator of St&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:37,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;567b36e32b926c3063c30662&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citm0wk4k042g34536hivsln0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57eaeb28d9b08ec06a77bd28&quot;,&quot;upvotes&quot;:1,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-27T21:56:56.420Z&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;@bmlyon I am always talking about JS only from the browser perspective and don&amp;#39;t care much about server-side JS and native apps written with JS. JavaScript will never conquer the world and it primary purpsoe still will be the browser scripting (at least until WebAssembly). Use right tool for the right job. For server-side I am still using PHP since it was invented to do so and PHP7 is as same fast as Node.js. For MacOS, iOS I use Swift. When you need something lower-level there is C/C++ or at least Java.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;@bmlyon I am always talking about JS only from the browser perspective and don&#39;t care much about server-side JS and native apps written with JS. For server-side I am still using PHP since it was invented to do so and PHP7 is as same fast as Node.js. For MacOS, iOS I use Swift. When you need something lower-level there is C/C++ or at least Java.&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;56f5a72f9625fc49458f85f2&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;mevrael&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Mev-Rael&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1458939712/pyfmbtkvtyiadipdsj0a.jpg&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Leader, AI Architect at Bunny AI and creator of BunnyJS&quot;,&quot;coverImage&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1497817693/cvnu3rccusefxyi8vij9.png&quot;,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[],&quot;totalUpvotesReceived&quot;:1613,&quot;appreciations&quot;:[{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab8&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ec2e41ff0411d5a48bad0b&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:8},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5aba&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57d39690314b9858e32216b1&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:16},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab9&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57d3250cf72dd3705c15fafb&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:12},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ac0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;579a23b3becb9ebac0d6014b&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:17},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abf&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;577e067a089a4f8e7884158e&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:13},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;577d80561e03c69a78fb0df0&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:49},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abe&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;577d6440f5d62870bc1e3457&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:43},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abc&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;576fed9a3d3400d0886600c3&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:27},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abb&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57152caf963e55c89fcd4591&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:16}],&quot;dateJoined&quot;:&quot;2016-03-25T21:01:35.400Z&quot;,&quot;socialMedia&quot;:{&quot;linkedin&quot;:&quot;https://linkedin.com/in/mevrael&quot;,&quot;stackoverflow&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;google&quot;:&quot;https://plus.google.com/+MevRaelDe&quot;,&quot;facebook&quot;:&quot;https://www.facebook.com/mevrael&quot;,&quot;twitter&quot;:&quot;https://twitter.com/Mevrael&quot;,&quot;github&quot;:&quot;https://github.com/Mevrael&quot;,&quot;website&quot;:&quot;https://bunnyjs.com&quot;},&quot;storiesCreated&quot;:[],&quot;numFollowing&quot;:182,&quot;numFollowers&quot;:841,&quot;location&quot;:&quot;London, Riga, Bengaluru&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:201,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;56f5a72f9625fc49458f85f2&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citm1kvpz0hjaxi53t90ww4n0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57eaef9797eba84632db57c8&quot;,&quot;upvotes&quot;:1,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-27T22:15:51.192Z&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;Wow, that&amp;#39;s one huge text! I really enjoyed reading it. but I do absolutely not agree with you. So I am really looking forward to your article to see the complete picture :) But for now, here is my opinion:&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;A programming language is a formal computer language or constructed language designed to communicate instructions to a machine, particularly a computer. Programming languages can be used to create programs to control the behavior of a machine or to express algorithms.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Wikipedia&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;JavaScript is a &amp;quot;real&amp;quot; programming language, not a framework. It is a formal language used to interact with the PC, change its behavior and express algorithms. Even when many things are already implemented by the browser, just think about the standard libraries of languages, like C++, Delphi and Rust. They also do contain an awful lot of things which you do not have to write yourself any more. The power of the standard library is no argument for or against a formal language being a programming language. All the &amp;quot;tools&amp;quot; you quoted are just part of the standard library of the browser, supplied by web standards to make interaction with rich controls and bindings to hardware possible.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I don&amp;#39;t know why you would mention UNIX there. UNIX does also allow for shared libraries, which are big, fat constructs with lots of flaws, used by many programs simultaneously. Then there are distributions, like &lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;http://sta.li\\&quot;&gt;Stali&lt;/a&gt; which try to solve that problem. Oh, and do not forget about all the other distributions which all try to solve different problems - why not be pure and just go with a Kernel+the GNU tools? Ironically, it is quite similar to what you try to tell us is bad about JS libraries.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;The passage about frameworks is disagreeable, because neither of your &amp;quot;reasons&amp;quot; applies for frameworks, like React, which try to solve an internal problem one of the biggest internet companies around had. They do have money and people, so the first argument does not apply and React was built for their own needs and open-sourced for your convenience, so the second argument does not apply either. I am pretty sure that a lot of thought went into React (which, btw. is written in VanillaJS) in order to improve their overal architecture while trying to improve some other problems as well.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;The second passage does not make any sense to me, because you admitted that you actually wrote a library (MVC adapter) to make your life easier. What is the difference between using a 3rd party lib and using your own? Heck, I also write VanillaJS 99% of the time, but I still create libraries as I see fit in order to bundle functionality logically. Libraries actually are a valid architectural decision and, again, not limited to JS.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;The first halve of the fourth part might be agreeable, if not for the very dynamic nature of JS, where you have to actually run the code in order to find out what is happening. Will a variable contain a String? An Integer? Maybe an Object? What kind of Object? What about the surrounding closures? How can your static analysis grasp that? I get the feeling, that you completely ditch that fact for the sake of the argument.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;About that designer&amp;#39;s advice: It sounds a lot too spartanic to me. I wrote 50k LoC, then I notice that I have a bug somewhere, so I delete 50k LoC and just start from the beginning and try to remember not to introduce that bug again? No way. That&amp;#39;s not how you improve, that&amp;#39;s how you go mad.... :( Also no company in the world would hire anyone with such a mindset, because it&amp;#39;s a complete waist of money. Something like that might be OK for an artist, but not for a programmer - and I am pretty sure that it was meant like that (since you quoted Photoshop so nicely).&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Again, I find your post highly interesting, so maybe we can use this opportunity for a little discussion? :)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;Wow, that&#39;s one huge text! I really enjoyed reading it. but I do absolutely not agree with you. So I am really looking forward to your article to see the complete picture :) But for now, here is my opinion:\\n\\n&gt; A programming language is a formal computer language or constructed language designed to communicate instructions to a machine, particularly a computer. Programming languages can be used to create programs to control the behavior of a machine or to express algorithms.\\n&gt;\\n&gt; Wikipedia\\n\\nJavaScript is a \\&quot;real\\&quot; programming language, not a framework. It is a formal language used to interact with the PC, change its behavior and express algorithms. Even when many things are already implemented by the browser, just think about the standard libraries of languages, like C++, Delphi and Rust. They also do contain an awful lot of things which you do not have to write yourself any more. The power of the standard library is no argument for or against a formal language being a programming language. All the \\&quot;tools\\&quot; you quoted are just part of the standard library of the browser, supplied by web standards to make interaction with rich controls and bindings to hardware possible.\\n\\nI don&#39;t know why you would mention UNIX there. UNIX does also allow for shared libraries, which are big, fat constructs with lots of flaws, used by many programs simultaneously. Then there are distributions, like [Stali](http://sta.li) which try to solve that problem. Oh, and do not forget about all the other distributions which all try to solve different problems - why not be pure and just go with a Kernel+the GNU tools? Ironically, it is quite similar to what you try to tell us is bad about JS libraries.\\n\\nThe passage about frameworks is disagreeable, because neither of your \\&quot;reasons\\&quot; applies for frameworks, like React, which try to solve an internal problem one of the biggest internet companies around had. They do have money and people, so the first argument does not apply and React was built for their own needs and open-sourced for your convenience, so the second argument does not apply either. I am pretty sure that a lot of thought went into React (which, btw. is written in VanillaJS) in order to improve their overal architecture while trying to improve some other problems as well.\\n\\nThe second passage does not make any sense to me, because you admitted that you actually wrote a library (MVC adapter) to make your life easier. What is the difference between using a 3rd party lib and using your own? Heck, I also write VanillaJS 99% of the time, but I still create libraries as I see fit in order to bundle functionality logically. Libraries actually are a valid architectural decision and, again, not limited to JS.\\n\\nThe first halve of the fourth part might be agreeable, if not for the very dynamic nature of JS, where you have to actually run the code in order to find out what is happening. Will a variable contain a String? An Integer? Maybe an Object? What kind of Object? What about the surrounding closures? How can your static analysis grasp that? I get the feeling, that you completely ditch that fact for the sake of the argument.\\n\\nAbout that designer&#39;s advice: It sounds a lot too spartanic to me. I wrote 50k LoC, then I notice that I have a bug somewhere, so I delete 50k LoC and just start from the beginning and try to remember not to introduce that bug again? No way. That&#39;s not how you improve, that&#39;s how you go mad.... :( Also no company in the world would hire anyone with such a mindset, because it&#39;s a complete waist of money. Something like that might be OK for an artist, but not for a programmer - and I am pretty sure that it was meant like that (since you quoted Photoshop so nicely).\\n\\nAgain, I find your post highly interesting, so maybe we can use this opportunity for a little discussion? &amp;quot;javascript frameworks are useless&amp;quot;, why the fuck did you write one?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;If \\&quot;javascript frameworks are useless\\&quot;, why the fuck did you write one?&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57884a1e16a33191db0437b4&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;hugollm&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Hugo Mota&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1493350648/ccga4mcelll8cv8jegxw_cropped.png&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Code
