&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Wikipedia is never a source you should rely your argumentation on. Anyway there is a direct link from your Wikipedia page to a more precise section - List of Scripting Languages - &lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;https://www.wikiwand.com/en/List_of_programming_languages_by_type#/Scripting_languages\\&quot;&gt;https://www.wikiwand.com/en/List_of_programming_languages_by_type#/Scripting_languages&lt;/a&gt; JS was weak from the beginning and still doesn&amp;#39;t has many constructions you can find in many other languages. ES6 was the biggest evolution in JS for 20 years but &amp;quot;classes&amp;quot; are still far away from being what people want to see.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I mentioned UNIX because of it&amp;#39;s philopophy and simplicity. React or Web components, for example, uses these principles as well. In web you are building a lot of components and for the maintainability, reliability and stability purpose they should be simple, small and do not know about each other.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;like React, which try to solve an internal problem one of the biggest internet companies around had. &lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Can you provide me researches, links to the articles, precise numbers about that &amp;quot;internal problem&amp;quot;, about why people are using React and moreover I am interested in measured results (at the end was that experiment successful, how exactly, or not?).&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;wrote a library (MVC adapter)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I didn&amp;#39;t wrote an MVC library. The main architecture and most of components are part of business code and are only available within a private repository. Something similar to &amp;quot;jQuery UI&amp;quot; would be more correct.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;What is the difference between using a 3rd party lib and using your own?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I am using 3rd party libraries as well and do not reinvent the wheel if there is already one. Answer is simple - look, for example, on Bootstrap 4 dropdown. What Bootstrap offers you is a huge jQuery itself only because of a dropdown which is 2kb of Vanilla JS? Same is now with React, a lot of simple components but to make these components working I need to include React, Redux and some other libraries often.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I am pretty sure that a lot of thought went into React (which, btw. is written in VanillaJS) in order to improve their overal architecture while trying to improve some other problems as well.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;The most went to Angular and other frameworks, React itself still is a small UI library which suck less, a complicated templating engine. Problem is people can&amp;#39;t explain anything about their decisions, why they use it, what problem it really solves, how exactly, numbers, results. When people don&amp;#39;t know about the architecture patterns which exists for tens of years and telling you that React introduced it, well, this is not the improvement of the architecture. You mentioned &amp;quot;some other problems as well&amp;quot;. Again, may I have links, researches, discussions, results?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Will a variable contain a String? An Integer? Maybe an Object? What kind of Object? What about the surrounding closures?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Interface should be simple and static. If you don&amp;#39;t know the type of variable could be, then there is something wrong with your architecture and/or code. Also code should be pure and without side effects.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Again, I find your post highly interesting, so maybe we can use this opportunity for a little discussion? :)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;We can. Well, some complicated components such as Validation can be viewed as small frameworks. You can build own form validation on the top of it very fast.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;@maruru \\n\\nWikipedia is never a source you should rely your argumentation on. Anyway there is a direct link from your Wikipedia page to a more precise section - List of Scripting Languages - https://www.wikiwand.com/en/List_of_programming_languages_by_type#/Scripting_languages JS was weak from the beginning and still doesn&#39;t has many constructions you can find in many other languages. ES6 was the biggest evolution in JS for 20 years but \\&quot;classes\\&quot; are still far away from being what people want to see.\\n\\nI mentioned UNIX because of it&#39;s philopophy and simplicity. React or Web components, for example, uses these principles as well. In web you are building a lot of components and for the maintainability, reliability and stability purpose they should be simple, small and do not know about each other.\\n\\n&gt; like React, which try to solve an internal problem one of the biggest internet companies around had. \\n\\nCan you provide me researches, links to the articles, precise numbers about that \\&quot;internal problem\\&quot;, about why people are using React and moreover I am interested in measured results (at the end was that experiment successful, how exactly, or not?).\\n\\n&gt; wrote a library (MVC adapter)\\n\\nI didn&#39;t wrote an MVC library. The main architecture and most of components are part of business code and are only available within a private repository. Something similar to \\&quot;jQuery UI\\&quot; would be more correct.\\n\\n&gt; What is the difference between using a 3rd party lib and using your own?\\n\\nI am using 3rd party libraries as well and do not reinvent the wheel if there is already one. Answer is simple - look, for example, on Bootstrap 4 dropdown. What Bootstrap offers you is a huge jQuery itself only because of a dropdown which is 2kb of Vanilla JS? Same is now with React, a lot of simple components but to make these components working I need to include React, Redux and some other libraries often.\\n\\n&gt; I am pretty sure that a lot of thought went into React (which, btw. is written in VanillaJS) in order to improve their overal architecture while trying to improve some other problems as well.\\n\\nThe most went to Angular and other frameworks, React itself still is a small UI library which suck less, a complicated templating engine. Problem is people can&#39;t explain anything about their decisions, why they use it, what problem it really solves, how exactly, numbers, results. When people don&#39;t know about the architecture patterns which exists for tens of years and telling you that React introduced it, well, this is not the improvement of the architecture. You mentioned \\&quot;some other problems as well\\&quot;. Again, may I have links, researches, discussions, results?\\n\\n&gt; Will a variable contain a String? An Integer? Maybe an Object? What kind of Object? What about the surrounding closures?\\n\\nInterface should be simple and static. If you don&#39;t know the type of variable could be, then there is something wrong with your architecture and/or code. Also code should be pure and without side effects.\\n\\n&gt; Again, I find your post highly interesting, so maybe we can use this opportunity for a little discussion? :)\\n\\nWe can. on&quot;:&quot;London, Riga, Bengaluru&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:201,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;56f5a72f9625fc49458f85f2&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citmjqzl70k3hxi53l23rpqtf&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57eb66cd97eba84632db5851&quot;,&quot;upvotes&quot;:1,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-28T06:44:29.227Z&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;@mevrael Well, your view on Wikipedia might be outdated. Today, citations from real books, articles and statements are needed, just like in a scientific paper. So Wikipedia is indeed quotable, given that necessary citation is provided. In case of the programming language article it is. Also your link shows, too, that JS is a Programming Language. Here is another, concrete evidence, that being &lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;https://www.w3.org/wiki/Programming_-_the_real_basics\\&quot;&gt;W3C listing JS as programming language for their tutorial course&lt;/a&gt;. I yet have to see evidence against JS being a programming language ;)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;The UNIX philosophy and how stuff developed are two different things. So again the situation is very alike.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;About the internal problem, let me &lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;https://hashnode.com/ama/with-with-ben-alpert-cis53jvri0201hq53dm93l4e1#cis5gpgjx007h7d53g0dpsj5s\\&quot;&gt;direct you to one of Hashnodes AMAs&lt;/a&gt;. It&amp;#39;s not about numbers or anything, it&amp;#39;s just that one guy had a problem with the available tooling and developed a solution. React is like some packaged architecture to help you structure your app and people like it. That&amp;#39;s why they use it. If you want numbers, you will have to first explain what you want to measure? All results are only relevant when relative, so what do you want to compare them against and in what categories? I see great difficulty in such a benchmark, because React really is mostly about architecture, so measuring the structure of a project in numbers is a little...&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;You know, I wrote in my FSWD 101 that many people miss-use React. You might be on that track. React is nice when your application becomes so big that React is small. It&amp;#39;s OK, when you build a Facebook, but definitely a nuclear bomb to kill an ant when it comes to personal sites and the like.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Angular is a Google product, so I do not think that Facebook put a lot of thought into its development. And If you want to know what problems React solves, please take a look at the official homepage, everything is written there in the docs. Or read the Wikipedia page, which sums it up nicely.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;JavaScript allows for dynamic content and I think it&amp;#39;s a shame if you do not make use of that when it is convenient. It&amp;#39;s not about bad design, but leveraging the power of the language! Sure, an interface should be static, but why not have multiple possible return types, depending on the input? If you pass no callback, then you will receive a promise, else you will receive a return code (number). As long as these things are documented explicitly in the interface documentation, it is a valid design decision humans can live with; but machines cannot. That&amp;#39;s why we have to write test cases for every possibility. That&amp;#39;s why there are so many unit testing frameworks for JS out there.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Yeah, I am on Slack, but I prefer an open discussion. That&amp;#39;s what Hashnode is for, after all :)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;About that framework of yours... could you please read the headline of your homepage to me? Doesn&amp;#39;t it say &amp;quot;BunnyJS - Browser ES6 framework&amp;quot;. If it&amp;#39;s not a framework, why does it say so everywhere on your page?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;@mevrael Well, your view on Wikipedia might be outdated. Today, citations from real books, articles and statements are needed, just like in a scientific paper. So Wikipedia is indeed quotable, given that necessary citation is provided. In case of the programming language article it is. Also your link shows, too, that JS is a Programming Language. Here is another, concrete evidence, that being [W3C listing JS as programming language for their tutorial course](https://www.w3.org/wiki/Programming_-_the_real_basics). I yet have to see evidence against JS being a programming language ;)\\n\\nThe UNIX philosophy and how stuff developed are two different things. So again the situation is very alike.\\n\\nAbout the internal problem, let me [direct you to one of Hashnodes AMAs](https://hashnode.com/ama/with-with-ben-alpert-cis53jvri0201hq53dm93l4e1#cis5gpgjx007h7d53g0dpsj5s). It&#39;s not about numbers or anything, it&#39;s just that one guy had a problem with the available tooling and developed a solution. React is like some packaged architecture to help you structure your app and people like it. That&#39;s why they use it. If you want numbers, you will have to first explain what you want to measure? All results are only relevant when relative, so what do you want to compare them against and in what categories? I see great difficulty in such a benchmark, because React really is mostly about architecture, so measuring the structure of a project in numbers is a little...\\n\\nYou know, I wrote in my FSWD 101 that many people miss-use React. You might be on that track. React is nice when your application becomes so big that React is small. It&#39;s OK, when you build a Facebook, but definitely a nuclear bomb to kill an ant when it comes to personal sites and the like.\\n\\nAngular is a Google product, so I do not think that Facebook put a lot of thought into its development. And If you want to know what problems React solves, please take a look at the official homepage, everything is written there in the docs. Or read the Wikipedia page, which sums it up nicely.\\n\\nJavaScript allows for dynamic content and I think it&#39;s a shame if you do not make use of that when it is convenient. It&#39;s not about bad design, but leveraging the power of the language! Sure, an interface should be static, but why not have multiple possible return types, depending on the input? If you pass no callback, then you will receive a promise, else you will receive a return code (number). As long as these things are documented explicitly in the interface documentation, it is a valid design decision humans can live with; but machines cannot. That&#39;s why we have to write test cases for every possibility. That&#39;s why there are so many unit testing frameworks for JS out there.\\n\\nYeah, I am on Slack, but I prefer an open discussion. That&#39;s what Hashnode is for, after all :)\\n\\nAbout that framework of yours... could you please read the headline of your homepage to me? Doesn&#39;t it say \\&quot;BunnyJS - Browser ES6 framework\\&quot;. If it&#39;s not a framework, why does it say so everywhere on your page?&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;570cc097a813d4ceb0550fb5&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;maruru&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Marco Alka&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1469961782/if3shn8aspwcqlkpp9xu.jpg&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Software Engineer, E2.0 Evangelist, Hobby Game Developer&quot;,&quot;coverImage&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1469962307/kqizbhn4z8j6onrdkmuy.jpg&quot;,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[],&quot;totalUpvotesReceived&quot;:3165,&quot;appreciations&quot;:[{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5aba&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ac31c0acdcb6810ec2d83b&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:24},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab8&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ac31b8acdcb6810ec2d838&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:15},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ac0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57a050cee6e9c21356b91927&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:34},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abf&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;577a06bfa1ac2f52aea75708&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:34},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;576ee9faf95d0ee3e2d75c80&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:106},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abb&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5767e0ada841f03b9338c561&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:44},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abe&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5764470ca841f03b9338c419&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:68},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abc&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;575e9407ed4fa39df4f9af8a&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:43},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab9&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;570f4e11a918e8a3026ebab6&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:9}],&quot;dateJoined&quot;:&quot;2016-04-12T09:32:07.287Z&quot;,&quot;socialMedia&quot;:{&quot;linkedin&quot;:&quot;https://www.linkedin.com/in/marco-alka-678825a8&quot;,&quot;stackoverflow&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;google&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;facebook&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;twitter&quot;:&quot;https://twitter.com/minecrawlerx&quot;,&quot;github&quot;:&quot;https://github.com/minecrawler&quot;,&quot;website&quot;:&quot;https://marco-alka.de&quot;},&quot;storiesCreated&quot;:[&quot;595f89a27235df722d9e4b54&quot;,&quot;5953a468e69695c0e87436e5&quot;,&quot;58718f8a4bd824eaa1272b89&quot;,&quot;581adbbe6c2fec00ae8c0c6c&quot;,&quot;58134bf9cc3446062c875a30&quot;,&quot;57d170a7f5e82d1d7e53de15&quot;,&quot;57c6baf7fa91cd4e941da9ab&quot;,&quot;57c43cc8cb80370904fc5c4d&quot;],&quot;numFollowing&quot;:23,&quot;numFollowers&quot;:1066,&quot;location&quot;:&quot;GERMANY&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:377,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;570cc097a813d4ceb0550fb5&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citmn8cfn0kmtxi53uruld271&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57eb7da597eba84632db588a&quot;,&quot;upvotes&quot;:1,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-28T08:21:57.875Z&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;@maruru &lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Whenever you read or answer something always look into the context and stay to it. I didn&amp;#39;t said JS is not programming language, I said it is not &amp;quot;real&amp;quot; programming language in context of it&amp;#39;s history and purpose, it was designed by a great software designer for a one simple use case - to script a browser. It changed a lot for 20 years but still mostly used to do the same thing - script a browser and after that SpiderMonkey/V8/Whatever else will do real job. Looking out of the context and to be more precise - JavaScript is not a language but a standard and is a major section of Web Standards. This standard, if you know it good, allows you to do whatever you want. When your lovely framework doesn&amp;#39;t gives you a ready solution you still have to write vanilla JS yourself.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I have read that AMA and offical docs. Here is Ben&amp;#39;s answer to my question - &lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;https://hashnode.com/ama/with-with-ben-alpert-cis53jvri0201hq53dm93l4e1#cis61l3cl03u2sp537t6vw34q\\&quot;&gt;Describe in 2 sentences what real world problem React is solving?&lt;/a&gt;. He as everyone else tells that React gives you component-based architecture easy to maintain. Problem is people believe that they need to use React to have a component-based architecture, to have a lot of small blocks where you can easily replace/change one without breaking anything else, they need to use React when they have to deal with DOM, etc. You actually just said exactly the same again. There is no connection between that general architecture pattern and React. You can do it without React and you won&amp;#39;t have any problems, your code won&amp;#39;t be bigger. Actually React doesn&amp;#39;t provides any tools for architecture itself. Here is a simple real problem with DI: you have object A, B and C. B and C both depends on A, you want to extend object A and make these changes available in B and C also. What you need to do is to update 2 dependencies manually, i.e. B.A = newA, C.A = newA. Does React solves this simple problem? Except giving me cool architecture I already had for many years before React was born, what else React can give to me?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;You know, I wrote in my FSWD 101 that many people miss-use React. You might be on that track. React is nice when your application becomes so big that React is small. It&amp;#39;s OK, when you build a Facebook, but definitely a nuclear bomb to kill an ant when it comes to personal sites and the like.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;My time and experience is too expensive, I am not working on small projects anymore. My applications grows, are big and I feel myself very comfortable without React because I have almost the same architecture React tries to sale to anyone, but I know that I don&amp;#39;t need React to give it to me.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;About that framework of yours... could you please read the headline of your homepage to me? Doesn&amp;#39;t it say &amp;quot;BunnyJS - Browser ES6 framework&amp;quot;. If it&amp;#39;s not a framework, why does it say so everywhere on your page?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;ol&gt;\\n&lt;li&gt;Marketing. Same as JavaScript was called that way because that time Java was so popular and everyone was crazy.&lt;/li&gt;\\n&lt;li&gt;My own view on what a framework really is is different from what the most people understands by that term. Framework is something could be used to build/extend/adapt/configure your own architecture on the top of it and doesn&amp;#39;t dictates you what you should do and how exactly. You are not in the cage, you are absolutely free. BunnyJS right now is not a framework by the definition but, probably, later there will be something like BunnyApp where basic app skeleton and architecture will be set up. One of the greatest examples about the frameworks is Laravel framework (not Laravel itself). There are two repos. Laravel is based on it&amp;#39;s own framework which uses Illuminate namespace everywhere, it core components are based on another framework Symfony and it uses many 3rd party libraries by default like Carbon under the hood of all Laravel&amp;#39;s components and methods using dates.&lt;/li&gt;\\n&lt;/ol&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Yeah, I am on Slack, but I prefer an open discussion. That&amp;#39;s what Hashnode is for, after all :)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Hashnode right now is not designed for a lot of big comments.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;@maruru \\n\\nWhenever you read or answer something always look into the context and stay to it. I didn&#39;t said JS is not programming language, I said it is not \\&quot;real\\&quot; programming language in context of it&#39;s history and purpose, it was designed by a great software designer for a one simple use case - to script a browser. It changed a lot for 20 years but still mostly used to do the same thing - script a browser and after that SpiderMonkey/V8/Whatever else will do real job. Looking out of the context and to be more precise - JavaScript is not a language but a standard and is a major section of Web Standards. This standard, if you know it good, allows you to do whatever you want. When your lovely framework doesn&#39;t gives you a ready solution you still have to write vanilla JS yourself.\\n\\nI have read that AMA and offical docs. Here is Ben&#39;s answer to my question - [Describe in 2 sentences what real world problem React is solving?](https://hashnode.com/ama/with-with-ben-alpert-cis53jvri0201hq53dm93l4e1#cis61l3cl03u2sp537t6vw34q). He as everyone else tells that React gives you component-based architecture easy to maintain. Problem is people believe that they need to use React to have a component-based architecture, to have a lot of small blocks where you can easily replace/change one without breaking anything else, they need to use React when they have to deal with DOM, etc. You actually just said exactly the same again. There is no connection between that general architecture pattern and React. You can do it without React and you won&#39;t have any problems, your code won&#39;t be bigger. Actually React doesn&#39;t provides any tools for architecture itself. Here is a simple real problem with DI: you have object A, B and C. B and C both depends on A, you want to extend object A and make these changes available in B and C also. What you need to do is to update 2 dependencies manually, i.e. B.A = newA, C.A = newA. Does React solves this simple problem? Except giving me cool architecture I already had for many years before React was born, what else React can give to me?\\n\\n&gt; You know, I wrote in my FSWD 101 that many people miss-use React. You might be on that track. React is nice when your application becomes so big that React is small. It&#39;s OK, when you build a Facebook, but definitely a nuclear bomb to kill an ant when it comes to personal sites and the like.\\n\\nMy time and experience is too expensive, I am not working on small projects anymore. My applications grows, are big and I feel myself very comfortable without React because I have almost the same architecture React tries to sale to anyone, but I know that I don&#39;t need React to give it to me.\\n\\n&gt; About that framework of yours... could you please read the headline of your homepage to me? Doesn&#39;t it say \\&quot;BunnyJS - Browser ES6 framework\\&quot;. If it&#39;s not a framework, why does it say so everywhere on your page?\\n\\n1. Marketing. Same as JavaScript was called that way because that time Java was so popular and everyone was crazy.\\n2. My own view on what a framework really is is different from what the most people understands by that term. Framework is something could be used to build/extend/adapt/configure your own architecture on the top of it and doesn&#39;t dictates you what you should do and how exactly. You are not in the cage, you are absolutely free. BunnyJS right now is not a framework by the definition but, probably, later there will be something like BunnyApp where basic app skeleton and architecture will be set up. One of the greatest examples about the frameworks is Laravel framework (not Laravel itself). There are two repos. Laravel is based on it&#39;s own framework which uses Illuminate namespace everywhere, it core components are based on another framework Symfony and it uses many 3rd party libraries by default like Carbon under the hood of all Laravel&#39;s components and methods using dates.\\n\\n&gt; Yeah, I am on Slack, but I prefer an open discussion. That&#39;s what Hashnode is for, after all :)\\n\\nHashnode right now is not designed for a lot of big on&quot;:&quot;London, Listen, I don&#39;t think trash talking your own stuff is helping your marketing. But well, if you have a reason you have a reason. I just commented here because I got angry at your text anyway, so I&#39;m in no position to judge you.&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57884a1e16a33191db0437b4&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;hugollm&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Hugo Mota&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1493350648/ccga4mcelll8cv8jegxw_cropped.png&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Code Hero&quot;,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[],&quot;totalUpvotesReceived&quot;:192,&quot;appreciations&quot;:[{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ac0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;579183dd7bcf1160974dd828&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:1},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abc&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;578e61eb5460288cdeb6f1d5&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:4},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;578ac3924707d0cd1f85ff54&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:6},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abe&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5789eb55bf4bc726ca6491e0&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:3},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abb&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;5789e771f490149ffb3c776e&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:2}],&quot;dateJoined&quot;:&quot;2016-07-15T02:27:42.316Z&quot;,&quot;socialMedia&quot;:{&quot;linkedin&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;stackoverflow&quot;:&quot;http://stackoverflow.com/users/434293/hugo-leonardo&quot;,&quot;google&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;facebook&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;twitter&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;github&quot;:&quot;https://github.com/hugollm&quot;,&quot;website&quot;:&quot;&quot;},&quot;storiesCreated&quot;:[],&quot;numFollowing&quot;:8,&quot;numFollowers&quot;:66,&quot;location&quot;:&quot;Montes Claros - State of Minas&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:16,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;57884a1e16a33191db0437b4&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citmqeu9q01lgk5535u0blyim&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57eb9283ff0411d5a48babe5&quot;,&quot;upvotes&quot;:1,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-28T09:50:59.774Z&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;@mevrael&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I said it is not &amp;quot;real&amp;quot; programming language&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;It&amp;#39;s funny, because then again, what is a &amp;quot;real&amp;quot; programming language. It&amp;#39;s like saying cacti are no &amp;quot;real&amp;quot; plants, because they have no leafes. A language either is a programming language, or it is not. There is no stuff in between. Even in terms of history it is a real PL, because it was designed as scripting language (that&amp;#39;s what you say) and a scripting language is a programming language. The interpreter will not do the job for you, it will only interpret your program and connect it to functionalities supplied by your browser or Node.JS or Electron or...&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript\\&quot;&gt;JavaScript is not a standard, it is a language based on ECMAScript&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;JavaScript (JS) is a lightweight, interpreted, programming language [..] The standard for JavaScript is ECMAScript.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;hr&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;[..] they need to use React when they have to deal with DOM, etc. You actually just said exactly the same again&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Where did I say that you need React? My statement is that an architecture, like what React gives you (Virtual DOM), is important when dealing with big applications. That&amp;#39;s also in my answer to the OP. And I fully agree that a lot too many developers think they have to use React for everything. It is very scary, just looking at Hashnode and all the people enforcing React, how many new big web apps are being worked on and should be released, if everyone had ligimate reasons :) I have not learned React and I am fighting against learning Angular and other frameworks, because I do think they overcomplicate a lot of problems. Either way, there are people who, in their heads, need these libraries. And even if it&amp;#39;s only a mental thing, it&amp;#39;s a reason for them to use those libraries and build great websites and applications. Personally, I don&amp;#39;t judge. I don&amp;#39;t care. If they can handle it and work with it, that&amp;#39;s OK. People are different, after all! I think, as a user, in this very special case, that the result is more important than how they got there.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;My time and experience is too expensive, I am not working on small projects anymore.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I do not see how experience and time have anything to do with project size. My job is to build appliances which are needed by my department and to build prototypes and experiment with certain new technology. I never have the chance to build big applications. Does that mean that I do not have any experience at all? That my labour force is cheap? That I have too much time?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Marketing. Same as JavaScript was called that way because that time Java was so popular and everyone was crazy.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;http://www.infoworld.com/article/2653798/application-development/javascript-creator-ponders-past--future.html\\&quot;&gt;That&amp;#39;s not what the inventor of JavaScript says...&lt;/a&gt; Also why would you spread false information, even though you allegedly know better?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;My own view on what a framework really is is different from what the most people understands by that term. &lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;It&amp;#39;s not about your own view, but about the definition. If we talk about our own ideas of things, then a computer is an animal which lives in the subtropics and eats sun rays (proof me wrong). Could you please find me an official source which explains, what a framework is and &lt;em&gt;why yours is not&lt;/em&gt;? Because it&amp;#39;s hard to find anything supporting your statement...&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Hashnode right now is not designed for a lot of big comments.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Haha, very true, I am actually writing my answer into notepad right now just so that I can see your text while typing :D&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;@mevrael\\n\\n&gt; I said it is not \\&quot;real\\&quot; programming language\\n\\nIt&#39;s funny, because then again, what is a \\&quot;real\\&quot; programming language. It&#39;s like saying cacti are no \\&quot;real\\&quot; plants, because they have no leafes. A language either is a programming language, or it is not. There is no stuff in between. Even in terms of history it is a real PL, because it was designed as scripting language (that&#39;s what you say) and a scripting language is a programming language. The interpreter will not do the job for you, it will only interpret your program and connect it to functionalities supplied by your browser or Node.JS or Electron or...\\n\\n[JavaScript is not a standard, it is a language based on ECMAScript](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript):\\n&gt; JavaScript (JS) is a lightweight, interpreted, programming language [..] The standard for JavaScript is ECMAScript.\\n\\n----\\n&gt; [..] they need to use React when they have to deal with DOM, etc. You actually just said exactly the same again\\n\\nWhere did I say that you need React? My statement is that an architecture, like what React gives you (Virtual DOM), is important when dealing with big applications. That&#39;s also in my answer to the OP. And I fully agree that a lot too many developers think they have to use React for everything. It is very scary, just looking at Hashnode and all the people enforcing React, how many new big web apps are being worked on and should be released, if everyone had ligimate reasons :) I have not learned React and I am fighting against learning Angular and other frameworks, because I do think they overcomplicate a lot of problems. Either way, there are people who, in their heads, need these libraries. And even if it&#39;s only a mental thing, it&#39;s a reason for them to use those libraries and build great websites and applications. Personally, I don&#39;t judge. I don&#39;t care. If they can handle it and work with it, that&#39;s OK. People are different, after all! I think, as a user, in this very special case, that the result is more important than how they got there.\\n\\n\\n&gt; My time and experience is too expensive, I am not working on small projects anymore.\\n\\nI do not see how experience and time have anything to do with project size. My job is to build appliances which are needed by my department and to build prototypes and experiment with certain new technology. I never have the chance to build big applications. Does that mean that I do not have any experience at all? That my labour force is cheap? That I have too much time?\\n\\n\\n&gt; Marketing. Same as JavaScript was called that way because that time Java was so popular and everyone was crazy.\\n\\n[That&#39;s not what the inventor of JavaScript says...](http://www.infoworld.com/article/2653798/application-development/javascript-creator-ponders-past--future.html) Also why would you spread false information, even though you allegedly know better?\\n\\n\\n&gt; My own view on what a framework really is is different from what the most people understands by that term. \\n\\nIt&#39;s not about your own view, but about the definition. If we talk about our own ideas of things, then a computer is an animal which lives in the subtropics and eats sun rays (proof me wrong). Could you please find me an official source which explains, what a framework is and _why yours is not_? Because it&#39;s hard to find anything supporting your statement...\\n\\n\\n&gt; Hashnode right now is not designed for a lot of big comments.\\n\\nHaha, very true, I am actually writing my answer into notepad right now just so that I can see your text while typing t;,&quot;581adbbe6c2fec00ae8c0c6c&quot;,&quot;58134bf9cc3446062c875a30&quot;,&quot;57d170a7f5e82d1d7e53de15&quot;,&quot;57c6baf7fa91cd4e941da9ab&quot;,&quot;57c43cc8cb80370904fc5c4d&quot;],&quot;numFollowing&quot;:23,&quot;numFollowers&quot;:1066,&quot;location&quot;:&quot;GERMANY&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:377,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;570cc097a813d4ceb0550fb5&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citmurxvg0lznxi536tet0zvj&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ebaf2597eba84632db58fd&quot;,&quot;upvotes&quot;:1,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-28T11:53:09.436Z&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;@maruru &lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;My statement is that an architecture, like what React gives you (Virtual DOM), is important when dealing with big applications.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Why it&amp;#39;s important? Virtual DOM is a marketing around a virtual problem doesn&amp;#39;t exists. So far I&amp;#39;ve seen only one benchmark showed React was a bit faster then vanilla JS to sort a huge table a lot of times per second which by the fact won&amp;#39;t ever happen in real life. Avarage human reaction is 300ms, changes in the UI are called by user actions, screen size physically is very limited, etc. Under the hood it, of course, calls vanilla JS DOM API itself. I&amp;#39;m sure even using VirtualDOM people can write bad code. I have no problems with DOM manipulation and I am doing exactly what I want to do, no more, no less and for that I don&amp;#39;t have to store in memory a VirtualDOM and do a diff every time.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;So again what React gives me? I already have a component-based architecture, I already have DOM manupulation which is in most cases much faster and cheaper then React.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;And I fully agree that a lot too many developers think they have to use React for everything. It is very scary, just looking at Hashnode and all the people enforcing React, how many new big web apps are being worked on and should be released, if everyone had ligimate reasons :) I have not learned React and I am fighting against learning Angular and other frameworks, because I do think they overcomplicate a lot of problems.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;At least on the main topic itself we have absolutely the same opinion and fighting against the same problem.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;That&amp;#39;s not what the inventor of JavaScript says... Also why would you spread false information, even though you allegedly know better?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;In the link you provided Eich says what I have written. How my statement is false or are you always reading the words and not trying to understand the meaning altogether?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;It&amp;#39;s not about your own view, but about the definition. If we talk about our own ideas of things, then a computer is an animal which lives in the subtropics and eats sun rays (proof me wrong). Could you please find me an official source which explains, what a framework is and why yours is not? Because it&amp;#39;s hard to find anything supporting your statement...&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Exactly, there is no standard single definition about a complicated topics. Moreover, everything depends on context. React is a library or is a framework depending on what angle you are looking on it from. Never read words and sentences, always read what is under them and try to understand what other person tried to describe.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;This question is about a simple certain topic and now there is a huge offtop. I am not going to keep discussion about what is a framework, is X a framework or not, etc. This is very complicated scientific discussion which is out of the scope of this Hashnode question.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Call BunnyJS whatever you like. It doesn&amp;#39;t matter. Matters only the purpose, difference and benefits and they are obvious: Instead of including a React Dropdown which requires to import also React itself, React DOM and may be something else - you can simply include a 2kb stand-alone component which can be used anywhere. That&amp;#39;s all, you don&amp;#39;t need to read huge docs, you don&amp;#39;t need to setup, change your build process. Total file size is tens of times smaller and code works faster.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;@maruru \\n\\n&gt; My statement is that an architecture, like what React gives you (Virtual DOM), is important when dealing with big applications.\\n\\nWhy it&#39;s important? Virtual DOM is a marketing around a virtual problem doesn&#39;t exists. So far I&#39;ve seen only one benchmark showed React was a bit faster then vanilla JS to sort a huge table a lot of times per second which by the fact won&#39;t ever happen in real life. Avarage human reaction is 300ms, changes in the UI are called by user actions, screen size physically is very limited, etc. Under the hood it, of course, calls vanilla JS DOM API itself. I&#39;m sure even using VirtualDOM people can write bad code. I have no problems with DOM manipulation and I am doing exactly what I want to do, no more, no less and for that I don&#39;t have to store in memory a VirtualDOM and do a diff every time.\\n\\nSo again what React gives me? I already have a component-based architecture, I already have DOM manupulation which is in most cases much faster and cheaper then React.\\n\\n&gt; And I fully agree that a lot too many developers think they have to use React for everything. It is very scary, just looking at Hashnode and all the people enforcing React, how many new big web apps are being worked on and should be released, if everyone had ligimate reasons :) I have not learned React and I am fighting against learning Angular and other frameworks, because I do think they overcomplicate a lot of problems.\\n\\nAt least on the main topic itself we have absolutely the same opinion and fighting against the same problem.\\n\\n&gt; That&#39;s not what the inventor of JavaScript says... Also why would you spread false information, even though you allegedly know better?\\n\\nIn the link you provided Eich says what I have written. How my statement is false or are you always reading the words and not trying to understand the meaning altogether?\\n\\n&gt; It&#39;s not about your own view, but about the definition. If we talk about our own ideas of things, then a computer is an animal which lives in the subtropics and eats sun rays (proof me wrong). Could you please find me an official source which explains, what a framework is and why yours is not? Because it&#39;s hard to find anything supporting your statement...\\n\\nExactly, there is no standard single definition about a complicated topics. Moreover, everything depends on context. React is a library or is a framework depending on what angle you are looking on it from. Never read words and sentences, always read what is under them and try to understand what other person tried to describe.\\n\\nThis question is about a simple certain topic and now there is a huge offtop. I am not going to keep discussion about what is a framework, is X a framework or not, etc. This is very complicated scientific discussion which is out of the scope of this Hashnode question.\\n\\nCall BunnyJS whatever you like. It doesn&#39;t matter. Matters only the purpose, difference and benefits and they are obvious: Instead of including a React Dropdown which requires to import also React itself, React DOM and may be something else - you can simply include a 2kb stand-alone component which can be used anywhere. That&#39;s all, you don&#39;t need to read huge docs, you don&#39;t need to setup, change your build process. Total file size is tens of times smaller and code works faster.&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;56f5a72f9625fc49458f85f2&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;mevrael&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Mev-Rael&quot;,&quot;photo&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1458939712/pyfmbtkvtyiadipdsj0a.jpg&quot;,&quot;tagline&quot;:&quot;Leader, AI Architect at Bunny AI and creator of BunnyJS&quot;,&quot;coverImage&quot;:&quot;https://res.cloudinary.com/hashnode/image/upload/v1497817693/cvnu3rccusefxyi8vij9.png&quot;,&quot;badgesAwarded&quot;:[],&quot;totalUpvotesReceived&quot;:1613,&quot;appreciations&quot;:[{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab8&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ec2e41ff0411d5a48bad0b&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:8},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5aba&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57d39690314b9858e32216b1&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:16},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ab9&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57d3250cf72dd3705c15fafb&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:12},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5ac0&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;579a23b3becb9ebac0d6014b&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:17},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abf&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;577e067a089a4f8e7884158e&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:13},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abd&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;577d80561e03c69a78fb0df0&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:49},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abe&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;577d6440f5d62870bc1e3457&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:43},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abc&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;576fed9a3d3400d0886600c3&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:27},{&quot;badge&quot;:&quot;567453d0b73d6a82ac8c5abb&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57152caf963e55c89fcd4591&quot;,&quot;count&quot;:16}],&quot;dateJoined&quot;:&quot;2016-03-25T21:01:35.400Z&quot;,&quot;socialMedia&quot;:{&quot;linkedin&quot;:&quot;https://linkedin.com/in/mevrael&quot;,&quot;stackoverflow&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;google&quot;:&quot;https://plus.google.com/+MevRaelDe&quot;,&quot;facebook&quot;:&quot;https://www.facebook.com/mevrael&quot;,&quot;twitter&quot;:&quot;https://twitter.com/Mevrael&quot;,&quot;github&quot;:&quot;https://github.com/Mevrael&quot;,&quot;website&quot;:&quot;https://bunnyjs.com&quot;},&quot;storiesCreated&quot;:[],&quot;numFollowing&quot;:182,&quot;numFollowers&quot;:841,&quot;location&quot;:&quot;London, Riga, Bengaluru&quot;,&quot;totalAppreciationBadges&quot;:201,&quot;id&quot;:&quot;56f5a72f9625fc49458f85f2&quot;},&quot;stamp&quot;:&quot;citmwoe2y02i6k5530xai95uy&quot;,&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ebbb9fff0411d5a48bac37&quot;,&quot;upvotes&quot;:1,&quot;isActive&quot;:true,&quot;dateAdded&quot;:&quot;2016-09-28T12:46:23.050Z&quot;},{&quot;content&quot;:&quot;&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=\\&quot;/@mevrael\\&quot; class=\\&quot;user-mention\\&quot; target=\\&quot;_blank\\&quot; rel=\\&quot;noopener noreferrer\\&quot;&gt;@mevrael&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;So again what React gives me? I already have [..]&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;It&amp;#39;s OK if you do not need it. Just do not generalize your projects and way of working.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;In the link you provided Eich says what I have written. How my statement is false or are you always reading the words and not trying to understand the meaning altogether?&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;No. You said that JavaScript has it&amp;#39;s name because &lt;code&gt;Java was so popular and everyone was crazy.&lt;/code&gt; (which is a completely random reason), while Eich said that &lt;code&gt;the idea was to make it a complementary scripting language to go with Java&lt;/code&gt; (which is a very valid reason). The difference might seem subtle, but the resulting statements are very contrary!&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;I am not going to keep discussion about what is a framework&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Why not finish it with a solid quotation, then? A definition for a framework is nothing scientific at all. It&amp;#39;s just a definition. For example &lt;a target=&#39;_blank&#39;  href=\\&quot;http://www.riehle.org/computer-science/research/dissertation/diss-a4.pdf\\&quot;&gt;Dirk Riehle of Universität Hamburg submitted a dissertation to the SWISS FEDERAL INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY ZURICH&lt;/a&gt;, in which he defines a software framework as:&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;[A software framework] leaves enough room for customization to solve a particular\\nproblem in the application domain.\\nDevelopers who apply a framework reuse its design and implementation. They do so to solve an application\\nproblem that falls into the domain modeled by the framework. By reusing the design, application\\ndevelopers customize a (hopefully) well-understood software architecture to their own specific\\napplication problem.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Which means that someone writes a piece of software which solves a problem and can be extended/customized by application code, which has the certain problem which is solved by the framework. This means that a framework is a skeleton for the actual application or solution.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Instead of including [many frameworks] you can simply include a 2kb stand-alone component [..]&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Yeah, let&amp;#39;s agree on that! I think that&amp;#39;s the one advice which we really need when we talk about VanillaJS :)&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;@mevrael\\n\\n&gt; So again what React gives me? I already have [..]\\n\\nIt&#39;s OK if you do not need it. Just do not generalize your projects and way of working.\\n\\n\\n&gt; In the link you provided Eich says what I have written. How my statement is false or are you always reading the words and not trying to understand the meaning altogether?\\n\\nNo. You said that JavaScript has it&#39;s name because `Java was so popular and everyone was crazy.` (which is a completely random reason), while Eich said that `the idea was to make it a complementary scripting language to go with Java` (which is a very valid reason). The difference might seem subtle, but the resulting statements are very contrary!\\n\\n\\n&gt; I am not going to keep discussion about what is a framework\\n\\nWhy not finish it with a solid quotation, then? A definition for a framework is nothing scientific at all. It&#39;s just a definition. For example [Dirk Riehle of Universität Hamburg submitted a dissertation to the SWISS FEDERAL INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY ZURICH](http://www.riehle.org/computer-science/research/dissertation/diss-a4.pdf), in which he defines a software framework as:\\n\\n&gt; [A software framework] leaves enough room for customization to solve a particular\\n&gt; problem in the application domain.\\n&gt; Developers who apply a framework reuse its design and implementation. They do so to solve an application\\n&gt; problem that falls into the domain modeled by the framework. By reusing the design, application\\n&gt; developers customize a (hopefully) well-understood software architecture to their own specific\\n&gt; application problem.\\n\\nWhich means that someone writes a piece of software which solves a problem and can be extended/customized by application code, which has the certain problem which is solved by the framework. This means that a framework is a skeleton for the actual application or solution.\\n\\n\\n&gt; Instead of including [many frameworks] you can simply include a 2kb stand-alone component [..]\\n\\nYeah, let&#39;s agree on that! I think that&#39;s the one advice which we really need when we talk about VanillaJS long as you are using some form of module bundler (webpack/browserify/rollup, etc), you can go a really long way with relatively plain JS... The only reason I mention using a bundler is it allows you to write your code in discrete modules.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;As it is, you can go a very long way.  Also, it makes it easier to add micro libraries via npm after you&amp;#39;ve done this, which allows you to stay very close to vanilla while still being able to support a growing codebase.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;As long as you are using some form of module bundler (webpack/browserify/rollup, etc), you can go a really long way with relatively plain JS... The only reason I mention using a bundler is it allows you to write your code in discrete modules.\\n\\nAs it is, you can go a very long way. JQuery was the only external library linked but I never actually found where it was being used.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;It was quite a lot of stuff: a full, feature-packed SOA client, something I would call an ORM even though it wasn&amp;#39;t exactly it, a standard library of utilities and, more interestingly, a visual styling IDE for creating responsive websites based on tiling (like webflow), etc.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;Yeah, there were no tests and massive refactoring could&amp;#39;ve gone a long way, besides changing a few idiosyncrasies (such as replacing SOA for full-featured REST among other stuff). But that they managed to build all that from scratch and it, mostly, worked I find a bit impressive.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;The company eventually went under but the reason was not their technology.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&lt;p&gt;All of that taught me to always think very carefully before deciding to use external libraries or full-featured frameworks, as I know that we can work without them and have worked like that already. I still reuse a lot, but I do so critically and will write my own code confidently if I feel that that will save me time and pain.&lt;/p&gt;\\n&quot;,&quot;contentMarkdown&quot;:&quot;Pretty far, indeed.\\n\\nA company I worked in had their entire frontend codebase written in in-house javascript. JQuery was the only external library linked but I never actually found where it was being used.\\n\\nIt was quite a lot of stuff: a full, feature-packed SOA client, something I would call an ORM even though it wasn&#39;t exactly it, a standard library of utilities and, more interestingly, a visual styling IDE for creating responsive websites based on tiling (like webflow), etc.\\n\\nYeah, there were no tests and massive refactoring could&#39;ve gone a long way, besides changing a few idiosyncrasies (such as replacing SOA for full-featured REST among other stuff). But that they managed to build all that from scratch and it, mostly, worked I find a bit impressive.\\n\\nThe company eventually went under but the reason was not their technology.\\n\\nAll of that taught me to always think very carefully before deciding to use external libraries or full-featured frameworks, as I know that we can work without them and have worked like that already. I still reuse a lot, but I do so critically and will write my own code confidently if I feel that that will save me time and pain.&quot;,&quot;author&quot;:{&quot;_id&quot;:&quot;57ec1c8597eba84632db59c0&quot;,&quot;username&quot;:&quot;luord&quot;,&quot;name&quot;:&quot;Luis
